description:
EVENT: totally my Wednesday night go to restaurant now!!! I'm loving this place!!

SERVICE: excellent! Everyone here is so wonderful and pleasant! Amazing service! Bought us our food in a timely manner! Came back to check on us! Love it!!!

DRINKS: half price bottle of wines on Wednesday!!! Seriously my go to place on Wednesday's!!! Love it!!

FOOD:
Everything is excellent here!! Here's what we got...
(1) Tofu soup: good spicy flavors and tofu is delish!
(2) Kimchi fried rice: excellent! Nice flavors 
(3) Kalbi: marinate, so delish. Came with a plate of meat in a sizzle plater.

**OVERALL: must try place!
author: Mindy Y.

description:
Yummy Korean food....... but the food served here didn't agree with my boyfriends stomach or mine. Not sure what it was... as I review the health ratings..

We ordered three dishes, and they are listed below :

Galbi - so so good. Everything on the dish including the bed of onions was delicious. I really loved the light char yet the meat was tender and juicy! the smaller portion feeds 2 easily if you order at least a couple more dishes. 

Kimchi pancake - the best kimchi pancake I have had!! I loved how they cut the pancake into smaller portions and each bite was consistent. Kimchi, crunchy pancake, yummmmmm!!!

Chicken wings- don't order original. It's so basic and unflavored. Garlic was super yummy. We ordered half half and they charge $1 more . Not the best wings I've had - the batter is a little thicker and airy here but the chicken is moist, tender. I think the garlic flavor could be a little more deep, it was pretty shallow and only could be tasted on bites with the inconsistently spread garlic sauce.


FYI they have taken the seafood pancake off the menu because the owner is currently sick. It is a labor intensive dish and will not be back until she recovers.

Parking is iffy and the area is too- try to park close!

Otherwise, service was amazing and we would come back should we be convinced it wasn't this food that gave us both issues... but probably not :(
author: Karen H.

description:
Price is reasonable, service is good.
They serve us free desert( fruits and cake).
We definitely will go back there.
author: Erika E.

description:
Spacious dining area. Super flavorful. We tried the half and half chicken wings (sweet and spicy and the original flavors). And the tofu soup. 

Both dishes were super good. And the rise with the soup was amazing. It was like a purple rice  and paired with the soup it was a nice combo. 

The employees are super nice. They would come by and check on our table to see how everything was and if we needed anything else. 

Will definitely come back to try one day.
author: Bonnie C.

description:
I thought the food was pretty good. Came her on the 4th of July so there wasnt much of a wait. The server was very attentive and checked in often in how we were doing. Definitely on the pricier side compared to other Korean restaurants in the city and the servings sizes are not huge but just enough to fill you up. 

I tried the following: 
Kimchi fried rice - pretty tasty, not too spicy and more on the sweet side. The seaweed added gives a nice texture and flavor to the rice. 

Grilled asparagus - $6, small serving size, they use baby asparagus and season it with a sweetened soy sauce and season seeds. Good flavor and crunch.  

Garlic Fried Chicken - my favorite dish! They put it on a hot plate with garlic on top and you have flip onto the hot dish. Perfect crunch and flavor and the chicken was super juicy inside. Highly recommend trying! 

Sweet and Spicy Chicken - I can't handle spicy but my bf enjoyed it. Said it had a nice kick and also sweet flavor to contrast.  

Mochi Ice Cream - mango and strawberry $5, they drizzle the mochi with some chocolate and top it with kiwi. Personally prefer the mochi as is without extra sauce. Just tastes like store bought mochi, unfrozen. Probably could skip. 

Overall, solid place. Nice ambience for a date night. Would come again for the wings or order takeout. Be sure to check in on yelp and get the extra 10% off your bill!
author: Kristy L.

description: Great wings! Go for the original and ask for the sweet and spicy sauce on the side. They also have insanely spicy hot sauce you can ask for if you're so inclined.
author: Benjamin P.

description: Been here plenty of times before but thought we would "eat in" tonight by doing Uber eats. It's Sunday night, school night, everyone is hungry and waiting for Korean food. Initial delivery eta was 615, and it gradually got pushed to 7pm. Called to see what's up, turns out they gave the food to the wrong driver. Told me they'd get me a new order but to cancel with Uber and that they'd start making another order and be ready in 25 minutes. I cancel, call back then back in 10 minutes, and they tell me it'll be really in 25 minute. What happened to making another order right away?! Turns out they all of a sudden got really busy and couldn't do it. I tell them I'll come grab the food myself. I arrive 25 minutes from when they last told me, and ended up waiting another 15 minutes. They offered 10% off as a type of apology I guess, why bother I think, either do an actual discount or don't do one at all. Won't be coming back.
author: Long C.

description: It was pretty good, a bit pricey for some of the food. Expected a little better given the reviews but not worth it in the end.
author: Kuan H.

description: We all went to sf for the weekend for a birthday and I always wanted to try Korean food with cheese. We stayed at an air bnb down the street from here that's how we ended up finding it. Our servers were so nice and attentive to us the entire time. Even the manager came and talked to us with recommendations for soju. The food was unbelievable! I had the seafood ramen and it was sooooo good I didn't even have time to take a pic of it. The mussel in it was so fresh I can still remember how it tastes. We got the corn cheese and it was so flavorful you have no idea. I recommend this place 15/10!
author: Diamond K.

description:
I'm so excited that there is a decent Korean place near me that delivers! In the past month I've ordered from here 3 times already and so far it's been consistently good. 

Our favorites are the galbi, hangover soup, and japchae. The prices are not cheap, but the portions are decent. I've ordered using UberEats and so far I've never had a hitch in the process.
author: Jean L.

description: Ordered dinner take out for my family and we were super disappointed- galbi was completely burnt!! I wouldn't even feed it to my dogs. We threw out all the takeout boxes.
author: H S.

description: Hwaro is a relax, modern and hip Korean restaurant with delicious food.  Came here with my family and friends and we really enjoyed ourselves. The kids love the sweet potato fries and corn cheese. I mean who doesn't like fries and cheese? The fries were hot and the corn was full of yummy gooey cheese! We also ordered the Garlic Chicken, Kalbi, Miso Pork Belly, chilled squid salad, Vegetable Basket, japchae, Korean style pancake and the "old" Kimchi. The house made Kimchi was delicious but the best were the wings. According to everyone, they were seasoned perfectly and were finger licking good. My family and friends said they can drink the refreshing citron soju and eat the garlic chicken wings all day!  Being a vegetarian, I ate most of the mushroom japchae and enjoyed the fresh veggie wraps that I made with the veggie basket. The citron soju was indeed refreshing. We also tried the peach soju and all of us prefer the citron soju. For dessert, we had vanilla and Strawberry mochi ice cream and green tea cheesecake. The service was very attentive and we didn't feel rushed even though the restaurant was full. It was a scrumptious meal and we'll certainly be back! We want to try the hangover soup and the Korean ramen.
author: Robert T.

description:
We were craving Korean food and the Sunset is just too far away to scavenge for food. We yelped it and came across this random restaurant in the mission - was surprisingly decent.

We ordered kimchi fried rice, taco trio, and rice cake skewers. We were overly ambitious for ordering the rice cake skewers, but the taco trio and kimchi fried rice were legit. The taco trio is perfect for the indecisive folks since it includes combos of bulgogi, spicy pork belly, and kimchi. Kimchi fried rice is just delicious any time of day. I would not say this place is purely Korean, since the food does taste slightly Americanized (like all Asian restaurants in this area), but it was still tasty and filling. 

The restaurant is super spacious and we did not have to wait to get seated (the best of both worlds especially when hungry). I wish they had a food truck some where so I can get these tacos on-the-go!
author: Connie L.

description:
Hwaro is great! The food, I'd give 4 stars because it wasn't out of this world but nonetheless delicious and a Korean place I've added to my list of coming back to. However, it gets an extra star for impeccable service. My cousins and I came 40 minutes before closing and depended over an hour here and were the last ones in the restaurant. If I were the workers, I'd be annoyed but they treated us with so much patience and did not rush us at all. 

As for the food: we got kimchi fried rice, japchae, ramen, & fried chicken and they were all so good! I would recommend all these dishes.
author: May O.

description:
The food is pretty delicious with the tofu soup being warm, spicy. They give you some pickled daikon which is pretty damn delicious too.

The entire meal though was super expensive with $17 for bibimbap with Bulgogi. The soft tofu soup bowl was huge but it didn't come with an egg or anything and you don't get banchan here (or at least a wide assortment of it).

The stuffed mushroom though was not a great deal. $10 for a single mushroom was not that great.
author: Rohan D.

description:
Came here with a party of approximately 10 on a Saturday night. We ordered a whole bunch of dishes, which includes bibimbap, kimchi fried rice, seafood pancake, sweet potato fries, and one of each fried chicken (original, garlic, and sweet & spicy).

My favour dishes here are the seafood pancake and fried chicken. The seafood package is packed with seafood so you get a mouthful with every bit instead of a few pieces here and there. Fried chicken is crispy and delicious. Make sure to check in on Yelp for 10% off!
author: Galen W.

description:
Unfortunately, this comes down to UberEats canceling my order after it was already 25 minutes late. I know it's not directly the restaurant's fault, but if you're going to partner with a delivery company then you need to make sure the experience is solid across the board. 
Waited an hour after being given a time of 35 minutes and then the order was cancelled without  any reason or way to contact anyone.
author: Jay S.

description:
Great local place when you're hankering for korean food. Has quite a few seats, but it was pretty empty on a week day evening. The hostess ended up being the cook (they had one other one), waiter, everything! He did it all, but was still pretty friendly, albeit really busy running back and forth. Looks like most people do take-out, but it's still a nice place to hang out if you want to eat in. 

We got the bibimbap and kimchi fried rice, both which were pretty good. Bibimbap was pretty standard, but the fried rice was yummy! Wish there was a bit more though. There were two sides, kimchi and sprouts. We also got the green thai iced tea, and that was enjoyable (a bit sweet though!).
author: Alice K.

description:
Got takeout for bibimbap, kimchi soup and spicy fried chicken which came up to $50+

The kimchi soup was a tad salty but full of kimchi and tofu so it was filling. Bibimbap was delicious and just enough to feed one but the fried chicken was probably my least favourite probably due to such high expectations. It was crispy but felt that the sauce was just dumped on the top of a few chicken pieces rather than marinated in it or that the flavours were on all the pieces.

Other than that, I felt that the quality and quantity served didn't really equate to over $50 for takeout dinner.
author: Carmen P.

description:
Save your money for somewhere better.

I think its overpriced Korean food, but nice addition to my neighborhood. 

I've tried:
Fried chicken - I prefer the sweet spicy over the garlic. I wish th garlic one was more garlicky. The chicken had a nice crunch
Seafood pancake - it felt tasted heavy but it is loaded with seafood.
Bibimbap - tasted bland, nothing special, will not order it again.

Overall - nothing special, I only went here to try it out, I'm not interested in coming back to try the rest of the menu since it did not expect my expectation.
author: Toni Rose M.

description: Ordered pickup via grubhub only to arrive and learn they went "offline and didn't receive my order."  Too busy to call grubhub to refund me and asked that I, the customer, do it. Yet the owner went over to thank and say goodbye to a large Korean party that was leaving. Lame.  This is San Francisco and I will get Korean grub, which is probably better, elsewhere.
author: ree g.

description: Awesome food and very good service. Love the soju cocktails. Excellent fried chicken. Go there. Now!
author: mike f.

description:
Hipster meets fusion Korean food.

The decor is your typical SF hipster. Edison bulbs, string lights, and wooden bar. The layout is very "open." There's tables off to the sides, but right in front of the door, there is a random open space.

Fried chicken - We got this in both of the sauces, garlic and sweet-spicy. We couldn't tell which of the sauces we liked better. Both were very very sweet. The garlic wings were topped with lots of garlic that we ended up scraping off the wing before eating. The sweet-spicy could use more balancing. Dish came with pickled daikon. The wings also come out piping hot so be careful when taking the first bite.

Kimchi Fried Rice - This was my favorite. It's like comfort food. The rice was cooked nicely. It had really good flavor. I could kill a whole bowl by myself.

Seafood pancake - This came out on a hot plate. It was a little burnt but still good. I think the pancake could have used more seafood but overall I would order again.

Only complaint is the smell of the place. It has an overpowering bathroom cleaner smell that hits you every once in a while. i'm not sure if it's just an old building or if the pipes are bad, but it's a little distracting when you are trying to eat. 

Will come back to try the meat dishes and soup. Also, if you check in on yelp there's a 10% off coupon.
author: Junella T.

description: Came here on a Saturday night around 8:30 and there were plenty of tables open.  This place has pretty cool decor and spacious.  We ordered the kimchi cheese, hangover soup, and fried chicken (half garlic half spicy).  Everything was pretty delicious.  I wish the kimchi cheese came with more chips.  The hangover soup came with plenty of beef .  And the fried chicken came on a hot plate so you can flip the the garlic chicken around and cook the garlic more if you want.  Overall a nice place for a causal dinner and night out with friends.  Service was great and parking wasn't too bad.
author: Len L.

description:
My experience here was okay. Some words to describe this place: modern, cozy, warm, and hip. Good food and welcoming space for a date or to catch up with friends. 

Came here on a Tuesday night w/ my bf a couple weeks ago. The staff noticed us right away upon entering, but took a while for us to be seated. Service was slow that night, not sure why since the restaurant wasn't even packed, but it picked up as the night went on. 

Food was okay. Everything we ordered was shared/shareable, which was nice. We ordered the Korean ramen, Kimchi Fried Rice w/ pork, and Garlic pork belly. Only downside of the food was the limited banchan and the ramen. The banchan is not like your typical kbbq restaurant where they serve you 5+ banchan options. Here, they only serve kimchi and bean sprouts. Both good, but wish there was more in quantity and more variety in the banchan. The ramen tasted like instant ramen and they tossed in some spicy Korean broth. I was craving noodles that night so it was okay and filling, but I would not recommend ordering this nor would I order this again for $11. 

Kimchi fried rice had all the right flavors. It was pretty spicy for me and my bf. A simple but filling dish - rice, kimchi, dry seaweed, pork, and a fried egg on top. $13

Favorite of the night was the garlic pork belly. It came out last, BUT tasted so good. Kinda pricy though for $21. If you love garlic like me, then you'll enjoy this dish. Jam-packed with flavor, the garlic pork belly is served on a sizzling plate and is more than enough meat to share with another person.

All in all, I'd probably come back to try other items if I'm in the area and use that 10% off check in on yelp!
author: Debby N.

description: Hwaro is a hidden gem within Excelsior. This Korean fusion restaurant provides great Koren food, fun vibes with full bar menu, and delightful service. The kimchi pancake was amazing as a starter. Korean ramen, isn't that a no-no? Not here, it's an amazing dish full of flavor. Check it out and enjoy!
author: Matthew T.

description: Late post: quick early dinner: this place isn't traditional Korean bbq. It's more Americanized Korean restaurant. The food is ok nothing wow. My girl enjoyed the flavor soju and spicy squid dish . I enjoyed the fried rice and sweet potato fries. The one negative is the sweet pancake with ice cream. The pancake is pretty hard where you can't use a spoon to cut it but a knife. At lease the green tea ice cream is good. Overall it's a 3.5 star for food but because the service is really awesome , I give 4 star! I definitely wouldn't mind coming here for drinks and food again since it's close by our house.
author: Christy V.

description: My SO's colleague recommended this place and since he is a legit Korean descendent so we gave it a try. However, once I stepped into this place on a Friday night i almost wanted to back-out immediately - it smells a little funny, like a somewhat clean toilet but still smells like a toilet. I decided to sit down and still give it a try. The service is fast as there were only another couple who was dining in there when we arrived. The food is average or below average, as I have been to many good ones in SF before. Price wise, I think this is on the cheaper side for Korean dinner. So overall the experience is mediocre. The smell did ruin their rating in my case. I do hope this is not what they smell like all the time.
author: Jessie L.

description:
An excursion to the Excelsior has become increasingly rare for Jamie W. and me these days, probably because I currently work across the bay and don't want to deal with navigational complications once I get back to the city. However, we decided to try this place based on a recommendation from a fellow foodie I met in a yoga class. She led me to some cool places like Mozzeria in the Mission, which we really liked (review: http://bit.ly/2pEQQht). I thought parking would be a bear, but surprisingly there were free meters right around the corner on Santa Rosa. Piece of cake. There was just one group of rambunctious guys at a table next to the window, but otherwise it was pretty empty on a Wednesday evening.

The menu was smallish but nicely eclectic even if it was really Korean with a hipster attitude. As we were deciding what to have, the young server gave us a free mini-appetizer of the Sweet Potato Fries with Spicy Mayo (photo: http://bit.ly/2pEQzbq). They weren't deep-fried, but they were tasty with a snap, and we never turn down mayo. Jamie and I went with splitting three dishes. The first was the $6 Baby Asparagus with toasted sesame seeds served on a sizzling iron plate (photo: http://bit.ly/2pU6txS). It was delicious, just not enough of it to satisfy beyond a few bites. Our second dish was the $13 Kimchi Fried Rice with Pork, which was covered with a fried egg and sprinkled with strips of dry seaweed (photo: http://bit.ly/2pEQmYH).

This was good solid comfort food, a bit by-the-numbers but no complaints, especially with the mini-banchan that came with it (photo: http://bit.ly/2pi2EGy). Our main event was the $17 Garlic Fried Chicken, a hearty portion with at least ten drumettes stacked precariously on a hot iron plate and coated in marinated minced garlic (photo: http://bit.ly/2oRqbew). As much as I love garlic, even I thought the minced garlic was excessive and we ended up scraping much of it off to get to the screaming hot poultry. It came with pickled radish cubes which provided some relief from the sticky heat (photo: http://bit.ly/2oNmjg5). They appear to be searching for their bearings a bit, but they're still off to a promising start.

FOOD - 4 stars...edgy, tasty Cal-Korean with a few flaws but a little tweaking will help them
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...blessedly low-key on a weeknight
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...fairly quiet but mostly responsive
TOTAL - 4 stars...modern Korean spot looks out of place in the Excelsior but what the hell
author: Ed U.

description:
Not a typical Korean restaurant but good tasting food. It's like elevated Korean food. If not mistaken, the owners and cooks are Koreans. 
You can certainly taste this in their Kimchi soup which is spicy and heartwarming! It's accompanied by fluffy purple rice - a good portion dish. 

The half and half fried chicken is served on a hot plate accompanied by some radish and wet towelettes. I really like the garlic fried chicken but the pickled garlic seems to take away some of that greatness. I wish it was either raw or briefly sautéed instead of marinated with sugar. The chicken itself was crunchy and juicy! 

The place is nice and trendy. Wish there were more banchan tho. 

I would order the kimchi soup again!
author: WQ C.

description:
We keep coming back to enjoy the food and the company of the gracious host Ina and her brother chef Ryan.  The 12 of us always enjoy our evenings drinking pitchers of beers and numerous bottles of soju. This time we ordered double orders of fried chicken,sweet and spicy fried chicken,seafood pancake, japchae, kalbi and pork belly sizzling BBQ.  The sweet and spicy chicken was more spicy than sweet. The fried chicken was good but I prefer a thinner batter. But the wings were huge!  The seafood pancake was yummy and I loved the kalbi and it's flavor.  I could have eaten the japchae plate by myself!  Although the pork belly was on a sizzling platter - I want my pork to be crispy!  Ina and her brother Ryan are the perfect hosts. Our table is always set up just the way we like it!  And they don't even mind that we are so loud. 

And for all the dishes we ordered and alcohol we consumed - when we got the check - it wasn't that much per person. So that's my hot tip -bring a bunch of friends so you can share dishes and try everything!   We will be back to try that cheese corn and hangover soup!
author: Donna L.

description:
Our waitress was awesome in walking through the menu and giving us recommendations. She checked on us frequently however towards the end of the meal, it took a while to get the check. 

The menu has many items that sounded great and we settled on the taco trio, seafood pancake, and the garlic pork belly bbq. The food packed a flavorful punch and I would say my favorite dish was the garlic bbq pork belly. It was more garlic intensive than I was expecting which was great since I love garlic. I thought the seafood pancake could have been better. We also had mochi for dessert and they offered six flavors that night. I'd like to come back and try more items including their soups and the dessert korean pancake. 

It's a very modern space. While I was dining, I was trying to recall what was the restaurant previously and I remembered it was a Goldilock's. Hwaro seems like a great addition to the area.
author: Maya S.

description:
3.5 Stars

This place is sooooooooo cute. I immediately took a million photos of the decor and sent it to everyone I knew. It was pretty dead on a Tuesday and this spot is huge so it looked even emptier. Had originally wanted to go to 7 Mile House but there was absolutely zero parking so I looked super quick on Yelp and realized I had this place bookmarked. 

This place is no longer cash only which is good because we did not have enough cash to cover the bill! We got two sojus, sweet potato fries, japchae with meat on the side, and bibimbap stone pot. 

My main issue is the sweet potato fries were COMPLETELY over salted. They were hard to eat but my friend doesn't like to complain so he ate them all anyways but agreed they were way too salty. If I was with anyone else I would've sent them back. It tasted like someone dumped the salt shaker on it. So sad. 

I also wish they had more vegetarian/pescetarian options. They very easily accommodated me when I asked for the meat on the side of my japchae though which was nice. I let my friend have all of it instead. I think some tofu/shrimp options would be really good. 

Staff here is great. I think I saw the owner there again having a full meal (just like another review said teehee). I love the different kinds of soju and wine they have. Also kind of annoying is they just placed the bottle of soju unopened on our table both times. I rarely see this happen. Its like opening your own bottle of wine or beer. I'm pretty sure its industry standard to open the bottle before serving it. Also I was asking the waiter for flavor suggestions and he hadn't tried any of the flavors so he was blindly suggesting. I think this place def has some kinks but otherwise I will happily come back.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
This just might be my new favorite Korean restaurant in San Francisco! I used to frequent 707 Sutter and Cocobang but this place definitely hit the spot.

I've been pretty disappointed by corn cheeses at other Korean places around here but THIS was so good. Previous corn cheeses just left me thinking: "I could do this better on a random skillet with string cheese at home". But this one--we wiped it out in a few minutes. The corn wasn't too soggy or mushy, with a generous serving of cheese, and topped with tempura crunch, which was actually an amazing addition. 

We were a table of 4 but ordered SO much even the waiter thought we over-ordered. But with eyes significantly bigger than our bellies, we were prepared for take-out.

We ordered:
1. Topokki with cheese (4/5 stars)
2. Kalbi (5/5)
3. Seafood pancake (4/5)
4. Hot stone bowl ramen with spam (4/5)
5. Half-half wings (4/5)
6. Kimchi Jiggae (kimchi stew) (5/5)
7. Corn cheese (5/5)
8. Taco trio (5/5) (if you're sharing this... GRAB THE BULGOGI PIECE FAST) 

The portions were really generous so much so that we had to drag an extra table over to put all the food (we eventually also filled that table). Kalbi came with super fresh lettuce and all the necessary additive sauces and pastes. I loved everything and went home with my Korean craving cured and a very happy belly. I'll be back!!!!
author: Su Lin Y.

description: I had the kimchee fried rice and found it to be a solid entree. The fried egg, kimchee, and seaweed went well together. The seafood pancake was quite generous in portion size. It could have more protein inside the carb, but it was cooked well.
author: Byron H.

description:
I came here on a Saturday around 8-9pm and got seated right away, since they close at 10pm. We got really lucky and found parking right in front! From looking through yelp reviews to see what was most popular, we decided to order the taco trio, cheese corn, and Korean ramen with spam and kimchi for two people. We also ended up getting a bottle of peach soju to go with our meal :) Everything turned out to be super yummy and we ended up finishing everything we ordered! (This doesn't happen a lot because I usually get full really easily) 

I really enjoyed the Korean ramen, especially on a cold, rainy day. It's a bit different from the tofu soup at other Korean restaurants with ramen added to it, but I really like the flavoring and the ramen texture here. I would definitely order this again. You have the options of adding cheese, spam or kimchi for an additional price - I believe it was $1/$2 for each item. We decided to go with just the spam and kimchi since we're already having a lot of cheese from the cheese corn! 

The cheese corn has a nice presentation and tastes pretty good as well! I like how it has the Panko/fried bread crumbs along the sides and some siracha sauce on top. It is not the best cheese corn that I've ever had, but it is pretty good and unique from the other cheese corn dishes I've had at other places. 

The taco trio was super juicy and flavorful! It has three different kinds of meat I believe and I enjoyed all of them! :) i wouldn't mind if there was a little bit less of that orange sauce though, it was a bit too saucy for me, but that probably varies and I don't mind it too much so I would definitely order this again. Maybe next time there will be less orange sauce on it and not drenched like this time! 

I am looking forward to coming back and trying more items on the menu. Maybe the wings next time? And the hangover soup if I do a lot of drinking the night before ;)
author: Bailey L.

description: They have me on a chicken wing search and recipe copy hinge. The spicy sweet wings are the perfect balance of spicy and sweet. The service is quick and friendly (I always order takeout because I live close), and I'm yet to have a batch of under or over cooked wings. I haven't tried much else there, but be it that I love chicken wings, they get 4 stars.
author: Brandy W.

description:
Wanted to see what $27 kalbi tasted like so I decided to give this place a try. What I ordered:

Kalbi - serving size wasn't what I expected for something so expensive so I guessed maybe their quality of meat was suppose to make up for it. However, their quality was no different from most Korean places. The marinade was a tad bit too sweet for my liking. I ordered the short ribs ssam style to include some lettuce, ssamjang and garlic but they missed out on the garlic and decided 3 pieces of lettuce was good enough. 

Haemul Pajeon - $16, about the typical price you find anywhere. Cooked to perfection and arrived somewhat crispy and not to flimsy, just the way I like it. Though this was lacking a lot in flavor and wouldn't recommend it. 

Overall, average Korean food and extremely over priced. Well at least the kalbi was.
author: Vince L.

description:
I don't like this place at all. 

Came here for dinner and I'm not surprised it was empty. 

Got seated and ordered right away. They stopped by with a sweet potatoes (?) and mayo shortly after. Weird combination and didn't like the taste...

Ordered:

Trio tacos 1/5 did not like the sauce. 
Kim chi fried rice 2/5 eh I've had better 
Hangover soup 1/5 had more veggies and meat than the soup itself
Wings (sweet and spicy) 2/5 very sweet and nothing spicy. It tasted like lumpia dipping sauce...
Miso garlic pork belly 2/5 flavors didn't go together and pork belly was cut too thin

Overall, pretty disappointed with the food. The flavors didn't go together and nothing authentic. The banchan was mediocre. OH the water had stuff floating inside it (was hoping it was lemon bits). 

Won't be back.
author: Elaine C.

description:
Newly opened Korean restaurant in the Excelsior. They take reservations but not sure why they require you to arrive 10 minutes early to confirm your reservation... First I have EVER heard of this.

This is a pretty pricey Korean restaurant considering their portion sizes.
BYOB - Bring your own booze. They will provide shot glasses and bottle openers. No charge.

Korean tacos - pretty standard size. Taste was good. I liked how they packed each taco with a good amount of meat and kimchi.

Ramen - gooood. Though it was just packaged ramen, with packaged slice cheese, and canned spam. All ingredients you can buy yourself and make. 

Wings - YUMMMM WINGSSSSS They were good. Flavorful. They put a LOT of garlic on the garlic fried... idk what I was expecting LOL.

Definitely worth a try. They have potential to be a really good restaurant for the area.
author: Benita M.

description:
Came for the first weekend these guys opened up for their brunch hours. Got the "Hangover Soup" and pork belly on the side. 

I never write yelp reviews but this place is the bomb! Legitimate Korean food made by Korean people (heard 'em in the kitchen) at very reasonable prices. Service was good and simple, and it was an easy and comfortable experience all around.
author: Josh K.

description:
When you call in an order for pickup, & you get a really nice employee on the line, that's always a plus.

And when the food is fresh, flavorful, & introduces you to a cuisine that you're not already familiar with, that's always a plus.

I don't know anything about Korean food.  So Hwaro was a welcome adventure & experience.  The space (formerly the goldilocks bakery) is all shiny & brand spankin' new.  It looks NOTHING like it did before.  And the staff were really top notch.

My order was gyoza, the stuffed mushroom, & the pork belly entree.  The stuffed mushroom was a nice surprise.  Filled w their specialty beef & topped w cheese, it was hearty, earthy, & comforting.  A great appetizer.  But the pork belly was fantastic.  Spicy, tender, & full of flavor.  If I had known that Korean food was this good, I would have been eating it already!  The only negative is that my gyoza was forgotten.  There were 3 containers in the bag, so I didn't realize until I opened them at home that one of those boxes was holding lettuce leaves & sauces instead of gyoza.  The staff member that took the order repeated back the gyoza, but evidently didn't write it down, since it wasn't on the receipt.  Mistakes happen, & it wasn't worth going back for.  

Missing dish aside, this meal was completely delicious & an all around winner.

A great addition to mission terrace.

4 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description: What? A Korean restaurant in the outer Mission!   Totally found this place on accident and so glad we did.  It was definitely authentic and with a modern ambiance.  I hope this place will be around for a long time as we're so close to it.  Thank you for being here.  Ordered the Korean Ramen with the spam, the broth was flavorful.  The half half fried chicken was so garlicky and crunchy (must order).  We also got the seafood pancakes to push our appetite to the max.  Also not a disappointment.
author: Justin L.

description:
I was surprised at how delicious this was! I'm not a huge fan of fusion menus, but the dishes here tasted great. The interior has a very modern, hipster flair but the food tastes authentic. One downside is that dishes are pricey and you don't get the typical authentic complimentary side dishes. But some main dishes come with a tiny side of kimchee and pickled cucumbers. 

Bulgogi: really really good! Juicy, flavorful, not too fatty, and fantastic miso dipping sauce. 

Taco Trio: love the different varieties of meat in the taco and the kimchee! Flavors worked well with the tortilla. 

Seafood Pancake: I would've liked it a bit crunchier, but they do give a very generous portion of seafood. 

Kimchee Fried Rice: delicious and very flavorful. Highly recommend!
author: Carolyn L.

description:
3.5 STARS

The Excelsior is an under the radar neighborhood in San Francisco. If you're not a native San Franciscan, you've probably only heard of the area because of Joe's Cable Car Restaurant (now defunct) that was featured on The Food Network. Good riddens with your $20 crappy burger served on a plastic plate, $7 sharing fee, and side of stank face. 

Aside from awesome taquerias, Excelsior's food scene is non-existent until Hwaro soft opened a month ago. The menu is a mix of traditional and fusion Korean dishes (from Kimchi Jjigae to Korean Tacos). Prices are reasonable for SF standards and portions were generous. It's currently BYOB until they get their liquor license so definitely stop by Kukje beforehand and bring in soju and beer. Reservations accepted. 

~ * ~ F O O D ~ * ~
The banchans: kimchi  and cucumber salad were weak which is usually a bad sign for a Korean restaurant but the food turned out pretty decent. I like that they provide you with lettuce wraps upon request and they have purple rice (yay!) but they charge you $2/bowl bit.ly/2dE0nkp. 

*Kalbi: Marinated Beef Short-Ribs (LA cut) w/ banchan, lettuce for wrapping ($25) - 4.5 STARS
bit.ly/2dC2mjY
The table's favorite, the Kalbi was perfectly marinated and grilled. Each savory sweet piece was nicely charred, marbled, and very tender. On par with the Kalbi I've had in the South Bay. 

*Taco Trio w/ bulgogi, spicy pork belly, kimchi, lettuce ($8) - 4 STARS
bit.ly/2dp8cqL
A really good value since there were generous amount of tender bulgogi and pork belly but the marinades were both sweet. A wedge of lime would have been perfect to cut through all the sweetness. 

*Korean Fried Chicken: Half Garlic, Half Sweet-Spicy ($16) - 3.5 STARS
bit.ly/2cNwLL7
We requested half regular and half sweet spicy but received the garlic instead of the regular. The KFC batter is thick and crunchy and the chicken was moist and juicy. It was underseasoned but I prefer that over it being overly salty. The garlic mixture was raw, minced garlic and sugar. It was unappetizingly astringent and cloyingly sweet so we scraped it off. I didn't try the sweet spicy one. Accompanying pickled daikon was great - crunchy and nicely pickled.

Kimchi Fried Rice w/ pork, sunny-side up egg, seaweed ($12) - 3.5 STARS
bit.ly/2d8MMw4
The fried rice was on the bland side since the kimchi was mild and not very fermented, but the perfectly cooked egg with an oozy yolk added a nice, creamy "sauce".

Samgyupsal Gui: BBQ Pork Belly, spicy sauce ($19) - 3 STARS
bit.ly/2cXBRIb
It was a pretty large portion of pork belly but it was chewy and the "spicy" sauce was more sweet than spicy. 

*Haemul Pajeon: Seafood Pancake w/ shrimp, squid, chives ($14) - 2 STARS
bit.ly/2dDYfJb
The pajeon wasn't thoroughly browned and there was too much batter so it was doughy. Squid was chewy and there weren't any shrimp as per the menu. Dipping sauce (soy-vinegar) was good though. 

Kimchi Jjigae: Kimchi Soup w/ tofu, veggies, pork belly ($12)
bit.ly/2dL7k2x
I didn't try any but my friends seemed to enjoy it. 

~ * ~ S E R V I C E ~ * ~
All the servers were green but very upbeat, friendly, and attentive (kept our water glasses full). I brought a birthday cake as a surprise for the birthday girl and the server asked the birthday girl, "Did you want me to bring out your cake, or did you want to save it for another time?" 

FAIL.  

Understandably mistakes happen but going forward, they should pull aside the customer who brought the cake or wait until the customer asks for it. 

Since it was a busy Saturday night and there was a constant flow of customers, it would have been nice if the owner was proactive, pitched in with her staff and/or interacted with customers. Instead, she was having a full, sit down meal with her dining companion at the bar for the majority of time we were there (2.5 hours). Obviously, her restaurant, her rules but it came off unprofessional.

~ * ~ A M B I A N C E / D E C O R ~ * ~
The space is minimalist and hipster. Good for parties of 2-4 and there's two communal tables that fit 6 people each. When we arrived, the ambiance was very upbeat and lively with the pop music that was playing...just as any fun Korean restaurant should be (like Playground, Tonight, The Spot, and Toyose). 

The music soon turned into odd mix of slow, depressing jazz tracks when the owner started having dinner at the bar. Since the music was dampening the mood, my friend's bf kindly provided feedback to one of the servers. She spoke with the owner who changed it for half a track, then changed it back to the slow, jazz music, and returned to dinner with her dining companion at the bar. Again, her restaurant, her rules but she didn't seem receptive to feedback which is unfortunate. 

~ * ~ P A R K I N G ~ * ~ 
Difficult street parking. 

Hwaro is the first and only Korean restaurant in the area serving pretty solid food. Hopefully, they'll pave the way for more restaurants like this to open in the area!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Delicious!!! I went with a big group, so I was able to try a good portion of their menu.

Favorites!
- Taco trio: love fusion tacos! These were filled with variations of lettuce, kimchi, bulgogi, spicy pork, and a creamy mayo-based sauce to tie everything together. 
- Garlic pork belly BBQ plate: We were debating between this and the galbi, and I'm so happy we went with pork belly! Tender and flavorful, and went well with the lettuce wraps (wish they gave only lettuce, the cabbage included was odd). I enjoyed the mini trio of sides that came with it (kimchi, cucumber, sauce) to enjoy the pork belly+lettuce with. Highly recommend! 
- Seafood pancake: Although I wish it was a tad bit crispier, this was delicious and made for a wonderful appetizer. Dipping sauce was yummy--I wish it came with more!

Others:
- Kimchi cheese: Okay, I LOVE kimchi, but keep in mind that a lot of their dishes already come with kimchi. This dish was kimchi-overkill, especially noting that the majority of our dishes had or came with kimchi. I would pass on this one, and would try their cheese corn instead for some variety.
- Kimchi fried rice: It was good, nothing extraordinary. Standard kimchi fried rice that didn't have any wow factor for me.
- Garlic fried chicken: The garlic is apparently sweetened with combined sugar, but it just tasted (and definitely felt) like raw garlic to me. I would pass on this one.
- Sweet n' spicy fried chicken: If you like a lot of sauce on your wings, then this might be for you! Personally, I would love to try their regular bare fried chicken instead--the meat itself is indeed crispy and juicy!

I can't wait to come back for more; would love to try their korean ramen and especially the hangover soup that everyone raves about!
author: Kris C.

description:
Glad Excelsior/outer Mission is being put on the map finally! Hwaro is a good choice when you want something different, Asian fusion-y, or Korean!

My friend and I came and ordered 3 things (which was way too much for us hahaha): 1/2 garlic and 1/2 sweet and spicy chicken, the taco trio, and the hangover soup!
- Fried chicken: loved the KFC here, the batter was thick and crunchy and the wings were huge. The garlic sauce needs a little work (it's pretty much raw garlic and sugar), but I did like the sweet and spicy sauce (it wasn't spicy at all btw).
- Taco trio: Loved this!! I love Asian fusion tacos so we had to order this. The combo of kimchi, lettuce, and Korean-marinated meat was delish! They came with a pretty generous amount of meat too.
- Hangover soup: I thought this would be the most underwhelming but it was actually really good! The soup was very rich and flavorful and would probably taste good with some rice. The meat was suuuper tender in this soup!

Service was a little weird.. When we asked the waitress about certain menu items, she couldn't even describe them, lol!! Also when we got our receipt to pay with credit card (we split 2 cards), they forgot to include my receipt to sign.. Eh!

I would love to come back and try the pork belly, galbi, or the bugolgi. We saw tables ordering these and they looked great with the lettuce wraps! The lunch bentos also look really good and are nicely priced.
author: Tara A.

description:
We had bulgogi, the marinated beef with lettuce wraps and kimchi on the side. The portion is definitely big enough for two people. Loved it! 
Can't imagine how much of my grandpa loves the chicken
author: Chris C.

description:
Meh. Taste is not bad, but price and lack of side dish for a Korean establishment was what dropped the stars down. Also, we went at 3:30 pm when there were only three other tables with customers, but service was still soooo slowwwwwwww. Only bean sprouts and kimchi as side dish, cmon..... And add $2 to get the hot stone pot for my already over priced bibimbap?!??! No!! 

Won't be back.
author: Susanna C.

description:
The Glee soundtrack was playing on repeat the entire time we were in the restaurant. My personal hell.

Food was great. Fried chicken was light and crispy. The hangover soup was rich with tender beef pieces.
author: Liz K.

description: This restaurant really impressed me with the food, service, and atmosphere. The kimchi appetizers were fresh, the barley tea was perfect, and everyone loved what they ordered. I had the kimchi soup, and it was absolutely incredible all the way to the bottom of the bowl. The bibimbop was very nice, too. A testament to its excellence was the number of people who kept walking in for take-out while we were served. I would highly recommend
author: Richard R.

description:
We wandered into Hwaro at an odd time on a Sunday and it wasn't packed, but definitely had some diners. While I wouldn't go as far as to say that this is the best Korean restaurant I've ever been to, Hwaro had one of the best kimchi soups I've ever had. Seriously, it was revelatory. Extremely spicy with a little bit of sour/citrusy tang. It reminded me of the Tom Yum soup my mom made for me growing up. 
Often kimchi soup can end up tasting like cabbage soup that's slightly spicy, bc I think the kimchi juices slide off and the chef doesn't add more of those flavors back in, but this was not the case at Hwaro. The kimchi soup at Hwaro was totally full bodied in flavor - spicy, sour, and savory. Soup like this is difficult to replicate consistently so I'm curious to see if it will be as amazing next time around. 

The japchae was really good too...but that soup, man. That soup will be in the back of my mind until next time.
author: Alison H.

description:
Food = okay.

Kimchi fried rice with pork = bland. We were all looking forward to this dish, and were so disappointed by it. It was lackluster in flavor and spices.  $13.00.  

Hamul pajeon = good. $16.00. 

Fried wings (1/2 and 1/2) = good. Original & sweet-spicy. This was our favorite item. $17.00.

Corn cheese = surprisingly good. (I was expecting some awful rendition of corned cream.) $7.00

Pork belly with lettuce wraps = meh. Not what I expected at all. $21.00.

Hot barley tea = $2.00.

Coke = $2.00.

Beer = $4.00.

Service = friendly. 

Seating = mostly 2-tops and 4-tops, and a few tables with bar stool seating. I got us reservations but it was fairly quiet on a Thursday evening.

Prices = moderate to expensive. $88.97 for dinner for 3, with minimal leftovers. 

It's great to have a Korean fusion joint in this neighborhood but I hope they kick it up a notch, because the flavors were just not there for us.
author: Fannie S.

description:
I love this place in the neighborhood. My favorite is the Kimchee fried rice which you can make vegetarian instead. I love the RnB soundtrack they have playing and it's a cozy place to eat with very friendly staff. Ask them and they will give amazing recommendations. We were seated immediately. 
I especially have to commend the young gentleman who served me and my girlfriend. I believe his name was Kaly. He was so on point with the suggestions, and taught us how to pronounce the food. He was a really hard worker.
author: Chad M.

description:
Spot on for Korean food and slight soju drinking going on in this neighborhood.

Squid was chewy and tasty with their spicy kimchi sauce.  They have pork belly bbq and beef ribs bbq to order sizzling up! 

Ban Chan was adequate.  Their ramen soup was hot in temperature and good.

I would say nice addition to the neighborhood for Korean food and soju drinking.
author: Tiffany D.

description: Best kalbi in the Bay Area. Also recommend the getting 1/2 original, 1/2 garlic fried chicken and seafood pancake.
author: Chad L.

description:
This place is grrrrrrreat as Tony would say 
BUT
my only complaint is that they give you SO LITTLE banchan.  I'm used to going to Korean places and getting like 9 little plates of barchan! You only get two tiny dishes of cucumber salad and kimchee. 

Other than than I really like everything about this place.  The ambiance is casual-hip, the servers are all quite nice, and I've never had to wait to be seated, it's generally half empty.  

The food I ate last time I was there was great I shared the stuffed mushroom - which is a giant mushroom STUFFED with melting oozing delicious cheese.  I also ordered the pork belly dish, SO good and low carb!

I will be back.
author: Christina L.

description:
SERVICE: There were only two male waiters, who seemed new to working in a restaurant, because they didn't serve us any water till they bring our meal. The appetizer was served much after we ate our entree. It was not even busy because we get to pick out table for two.

FOODS: We ordered the tacos trios which were unique and delicious from other places. It's creamy sauce and tender meat hit the spot. The japchae and the bibimbap are good portion, but it doesn't taste like it's out of this world. Good to try once.
author: Yingying Z.

description:
Food was excellent and service was superb.
You also want Josue as your server - personable,  attentive, and the kind of guy you want at any restaurant you go to.

Half-half fried chicken - classic flavors for KFC but the chicken itself was juicy and tasty.

Pork Belly BBQ - can't go wrong with pork belly and very plentiful. Add extra spicy sauce to your lettuce wraps, and don't be afraid of the garlic.

Asparagus - lightly charred with sesame and smoky flavor. Surprisingly good.

Banchan was simple (Kim chee and cucumbers only), but our server was quick to ask if we wanted more. And you want more.
author: Russell T.

description: Best in town.  Been here several times.  Always very good food, people n service.  Great dive bar next door.  Pissed Off Petes
author: David B.

description:
UberEATS review: Ordered from them twice. First time they missed the Bulgogi, the second time they missed the wraps on all my barbecue items. Unacceptable service if you were to do delivery.  

Items are on the pricier side and tbh not worth it. 

Hangover soup - expected to have more soup... the veg and meat are overwhelming

Kalbi - small portion for $27, otherwise it's tastes good

Miso pork belly - salty. It would be alright if paired with vegi wrap

Japchae - great taste

Corn cheese - They put tempura crumb and tomato sauce... meh

Half and half Chicken wings - like the sweet sauce. They do put big chunk of garlic. Not impressive. 

End note: spent too much on a mediocre restaurant. not coming back.
author: Ada L.

description:
Food is really good! It usually takes between 15-30 minutes though, so be prepared to wait. The four stars (instead of 5) is for the wait.

I want to emphasize the quality of the food! Really savory and tasty :)
author: Austin N.

description: Perhaps my expectations were too high. I was hoping for very flavorful dishes, but everything was pretty bland. Dishes were covered in sauce, but that didn't help much. Our table ordered cheese corn, spicy squid, kalbi, trio tacos, and tteobokki--nothing stood out, and my friends and I left (after spending $70+) feeling hungry. As I write this review, we're heading to get somewhere else for food. If you want delicious and satisfying Korean food, just go to a traditional Korean restaurant and do not bother with this "fusion" place. Oh yeah, this is a small-plate place, and it's true...their portions are super small and not worth the $$$.
author: S Z.

description:
I came here for a girls weekend out. 

food

The trio korean tacos appetizer was amazing. The meat is juicy and tender and flavored sooo perfectly! The fried chicken was so much battered and so tasty. kimchi fried rice was done very well, it's amazing how they can make a simple food dish so delicious. In general, very deliciously prepared food! this is a family owned restaurant and I felt the family warmth inside each dish. 

ambiance and service

excellent! the owner came to talk to us and make sure we are taken care of.

wine

when the owner came over, we asked for wine recommendation. Rather than recommending the most expensive wine on the menu like most owners would have done, she recommended the cheapest wine on the menu. I think it was a sauvignon blanc. She said she thinks that will pair very well with what we were eating. She was absolutely right! That wine was so tasty and paired with the food was amazing! We asked her well and how she picks her wine. She said she went to visit a lot of the wineries in napa etc and personally tasted countless wines (can't say I feel sorry for her :)) and hand picked a very small selection for her restaurant. We were all very impressed

If I didn't live across the bridge from this lovely gem of a place, I would be dining here every night :)
author: Danika Z.

description: Yum! Great service and food. Perfect for a large party. :) :) Josue was super sweet and patient with the birthday boy and friends! Highly recommend.
author: Maria F.

description:
There have been many chances where I've been able to eat good ramen. This was not one of them.

The quality of the noodles is instant ramen quality. I'm actually quite confident it was instant ramen.

I added cheese. They gave me a single slice of American cheese.

Incredibly disappointed by the Korean ramen.

2 stars overall. One earned for service passing. One for the Taco Trio.
author: Alvin D.

description:
The Garlic Chicken was prepared well and looked appetizing, but let me just say that there was literally about 1/4 cup of minced garlic on the chicken. Even after removing it, the strong garlic taste remained. I absolutely love garlic on my food (I always add twice the amount called for in recipes, but this was way over the top.)

The staff was pretty subdued in friendliness. I'm sure they were very nice people, but it didn't show.

The decor was very nice. The walls were painted very hipster.

All in all, I wouldn't return but the place has a lot of potential for improvement.
author: Paul P.

description:
Awesome place in the Excelsior. Great food, reasonably priced, nice atmosphere and friendly staff. 

There is a wide selection of food on the menu and many interesting dishes. Hwaro's fried chicken is the best Korean fried chicken I've ever had.
author: Bill M.

description: delicious! I love their kimchi fried rice, and their fried chicken. Great spot for date night :)
author: Kel H.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Wednesday night with the boyfriend. We ordered the French Fries (topped with kimchi), Taco Trio, Kimchi Fried Rice, Japchae, and Kimchi Soup. Yes, I know, that's a lot of food for two people! 

The french fries were the first to come. A third way into the fries my boyfriend mentions that these fries remind him of McDonald's fries. He spent the rest of dinner convincing himself (and me) that these fries are old fries (when I say old, I mean fries that have been left out for a few hours) from McDonald's. Everyone knows what leftover McDonald's fries tastes like, and these kimchi fries definitely tasted like that. Don't get me wrong, the fries were pretty delicious (although it would've been better if the fries were waffle fries, so it can hold the kimchi and sauce more)! But the thought that these fries may have been possibly from McDonald's was just so shocking. 

Anyway, enough about the fries. The Taco Trio was very flavorful. It's an appetizer, but I think it's enough to be a meal on it's own. Kimchi Fried Rice was pretty good, good amount of spiciness but lacked a bit of salt. I was not a fan of the Japchae. I don't eat Korean food often so I'm not entirely sure what it's supposed to taste like, but the noodle texture was just not that good. I only had a spoon of the Kimchi Soup and I thought it was extremely sour. Not sure if that's what it's supposed to taste like, but my boyfriend enjoyed it.
author: Lina C.

description: Huge restaurant with tons of seating. First time here and probably my last. The sweet potato with mayo that they serve as an appetizer was weird. Such a weird thing to serve, or is it just me who thinks it's odd? My bf and I ordered the kimchi fried rice, japchae, and the half and half spicy chicken wings (garlic fried and sweet spicy). Favorite dish out of the three has to be the kimchi fried rice. Can't go wrong with ordering this usually. However, the japchae was not good at all. I thought it was just me, but shortly after, my bf commented the same. For the fried chicken, the garlic fried chicken just had a slab of minced garlic placed right on top. When I ate it, didn't know it was going to be like that so I bit right into a huge mouthful of garlic. It's weird how they just put the garlic all on top in one huge chunk. As much as I looove garlic, that was mehhhhh. The sweet spicy flavor on the other hand, was actually really delicious. For the price and the food, I'd much rather go to another Korean restaurant. Service wasn't too great either. However, glad I was able to try this place and unbookmark it.
author: Annie H.

description:
A new, modern Korean restaurant in the Excelsior playing bossanova? YES!

I was a bit upset when I saw Goldilocks close. I had recently been there and while it was my third favorite Filipino restaurant in Excelsior, they did introduce me to some new stuff.

My mood changed when I saw the sign on the door saying the new place was Hwaro, a Korean restaurant. Excelsior has Filipino, Japanese, Thai, Laotian, Vietnamese, all types of Chinese. But we don't have Korean. 

Let alone one that serves alcohol.

This week they are going through a soft launch - they don't officially open or have a working credit card until 9/5/16 - but are taking customers. The lunch menu is very different from the dinner, which also explains the large break in between.

When I walked in on a Tuesday, there were a few groups eating - and I do recommend coming here in a group or on a date so you can try more. I sat by myself and spent time on the menu. They have a number of small plates that sound great like the Taco Trio, gyoza, and asparagus because something has to be green. 

There are also big plates which are must shares. Three types of KFC (Korean Fried Chicken), kimchee fried rice, seafood pancakes, tonkatsu. They have Korean ramen and a Hangover Soup! 

I went with the sizzling BBQ eel. I love eel, heck I've had eel fried rice directly across the street. The great waitress warned me it was only 6 pieces but that was enough for tonight. Along with it came some lettuce to make wraps, some banchan, and I ordered a side of rice. It was delicious and it will be hard not to order it again.

Or live out a dream and special order a BBQ eel taco.

After finishing up I got to talk to the two waitresses, the owner Ina jamming out to classic bossanova, and the head chef Ryan. They explained some of the backstory, how they will soon be getting three types of Korean beer (including Hite!), shoju, and wine, and that the neighborhood has welcomed them. 

I really like Hwaro and feel it not only adds a culinary option to Excelsior, but adds a more modern option as well. With Rocks Den, Sushi Raw, and now Hwaro, this part of Excelsior is getting some gentrification. Not white people (says the white person), but more gentrifying for Millenials - modern locations with a modern vibe. I don't want the area to be completely changed - I may actually be addicted to Baby's lumpia - but I like that we are getting options to take groups or dates to. Excelsior isn't only for cheap lunch, and Hwaro helps this.

UPDATE: I came over for lunch and got the sweet and spicy fried chicken bento and the pork belly quesadilla. The bento came with side salad, some of the least greasy japchae I've ever had, two dumplings, rice, kimchi and 4 wings covered in sauce. Ask for extra napkins! I definitely got a lot of sauce on my face/beard. The wings were cooked perfectly, and the sauce was both sweet and spicy. Not bad for the amount of food I got.

But the pork belly quesadilla stole the show! I want one right now. Full of delicious pork belly, kimchi, cheese, sauce, and I want to say butter because it was decadent. Still can't wait to bring people here.

Update 9/18: Took two friends here for dinner to finally get a group dinner going. We got:
-Corn Cheese - basically a skillet filled with sweet corn and mozzarella cheese. Two things I love
-Gyoza - I'm a sucker for dumplings
-Rice Cake Skewers - Because it was my birthday, the owner gave these to us on the house, and explained that growing up in Korea, this was one of her favorite street food snacks. We got two skewers with about 5 rice cakes on top, covered in the sweet and spicy sauce from the chicken wings. If you like sweet and spicy, these are really good, a bit chewy. Glad I got to try these!
-Kimchee Pancake - one of my guests doesn't like seafood, which is why we got this. Turns out he also doesn't like kimchee, SMH. This was delicious.
-Kimchee Fried Rice - yeah, my friend didn't have the best meal, but his loss. This was delicious, spicy fried rice with some seaweed which gives it a really interesting flavor. But man that pork belly is so good.

Oh, and for my return trip I was recommended trying the miso pork belly.

Also they have the cleanest bathroom in Excelsior.
author: Michael C.

description:
My friends and I went to an event and we were seriously super hungry afterwards. We were craving Korean food and had to quickly pick a random place nearby that was open since most Korean restaurants close midday. We eventually found this place that looked really nice from the pictures. 

We arrived to the area and I'm being serious when I say the location was really sketchy and scary. My friend got hit on by an old man, another old man waving at us from above his apartment with a Chucky doll, and there were even boys calling us from across the street. No joke, this all happened just walking 2 blocks down to the restaurant. I know this doesn't have anything to do with the restaurant itself, but I thought I would mention it just for the safety of it.

Anyways, we came in and it was pretty empty except for 3 middle aged and elderly men sitting near the counter(?). We all thought they were employees at first, but they kept staring over at our table. Literally without any shame. They even turned around to watch my friends walk towards the bathroom. Overall, for the location and experience I would have given it a 1 or 2 star(s).

NOW ONTO THE FOOD. My friends ordered bibimbap, taco trio, and kimchi fried rice with pork (?), while I ordered tteokbokki with ramen. I can't speak for my friends' meals, but they all really liked their food. I also really enjoyed my meal as well! Maybe personally for me, the sauce was a bit salty, but I still enjoyed it. 

Lastly, the service was pretty good. Not amazing, but better than most places. They were very friendly and kind. The only issue was that they were a bit slow and didn't seem to pay attention when we called them at times even though the restaurant was empty once those creepy men left. 

I was debating on giving this place three stars, but despite everything, I still liked the food, so four stars it is lmao!
author: Sharon T.

description:
didn't hear one person laugh the first 15-20 mins* i was in the mzafza. no wonder i'm single - if all those dullazz convos are what dating is, remind me to delete my tinderoni and not even bother getting my own cookie lyon. wait no i do want a cookie lyon.

TL;DR once the chicken's fully cooked this will be one of my #guiltypleasure / #straightfromthegym spots.

NLE;DR only reason i'm not saying 4 stars is too many pieces of pinkish / rawish fried chicken. but i told ms owner #ladiesispimpstoo, and i'm confident their fry game can rectify #soquicksofast.

(-_^) Sweet-Spicy Fried Chicken $8/$16 (http://bit.ly/2btJKEo)
very sweet, not spicy. generous crust

(-_^) Garlic Fried Chicken $8/$16 (http://bit.ly/2bTm5OZ)
"garlic heaven". bigbody crust

(-_^) Taco Trio $8 (http://bit.ly/2btKdqf)
wish other k tacos would learn from these
also wish tortillas warm or lightly toasted

MUSIC likeabossanova, jazz

PATRONS families, coughboringcough dates

SILVERWARE some ikea (that's a good thing)

DECOR classyish yet spacious enough to relax

alcohol and more menu items planned. i'll give them time before returning. but you can bet it'll be on my mind till then. #datnunadoe ;p

*yes i timed it beezys. for your educational benefit.
author: Dan B.

description:
The restaurant is not fully open yet but they are taking customers while they tie up all the loose ends. 

The hangover soup is amazing, the perfect amount of meats, veggies and spices to cure the worst of headaches. They take a unique spin on traditional Korean plates such as honey glazed fried chicken and mozarella fish cakes while carrying the traditional items like bibimbap and seafood pancakes. 

The decor is warm and inviting so you feel at home here.

The staff is very sweet and eager to help.

Definitely worth a visit.
author: Y L.

description:
Everything is good! The taste and size of the food, the atmosphere, and the people! They are so friendly, especially the owner Ina and the chef her brother. It's one of the most authentic Korean food in the city. My favorite are kimchi fried rice and fried chicken!! 

btw, they make the kimchi themselves. It's not from a third supply chain. I'm not a kimchi fan, but I really like their kimchi. You can tell it's really fresh and taste good. I would definitely come back!
author: Kathleen K.

description:
Really good place with good solid food.

We tried the KFC, "Korean Fried Chicken", we requested 1/2 Garlic & !/2 Sweet and Spicy.
The chicken was really moist. The sweet & spicy was a bit messy to eat, but just work your way through it. It's worth it. This portion is huge, appx 10 pieces total, my wife and I took 6 pieces home.

We also tried the grilled skewered rice, first time having this ever. 

Ina, I'm assuming the owner, mentioned she wanted to introduce it to San Francisco.
Beer and Wine not yet available, but you are free to bring your own bottles.

Thank you to Team Hwaro for bringing a Korean restaurant nearby,
author: Geordie E.

description: What a great addition to the neighborhood! I'd been meaning to try Hwaro ever since it opened and was glad to find the opportunity to go last weekend. They have two veg main dishes, Bibimbap and Japchae, and multiple sides. My partner and I ordered both and shared them, both were excellent. My only complaint was that the music was too loud. Service was attentive and friendly, and the portions were generous. We also had some of the best sweet potato fries I've had in a long time, and kimchi tacos! I'll definitely be back.
author: Gaelen X.

description: My favorite Korean restaurant in SF hands down. Staff is always friendly and helpful. Delicious food, great ambiance...perfect for groups or for a cozy dinner...what more can I ask for?
author: Rosa A.

description:
Solid place. I had the original recipe fried chicken from the brunch menu and it was great. Not
Korean fried chicken per se (e.g., no spice or sweet elements in the flavoring), but the batter was very crisp and thin like a delicious Korean fried chicken or Taiwanese popcorn chicken situation. Service was great and the place is very nice. I hope they do well!
author: Ray N.

description:
Super!! Great service! Ramen was our FAVORITE :)  Enjoyed the atmosphere too.
We had Bulgogi and fried chicken both delicious.
author: Jason S.

description: Good Korean in SF is sometimes hard to find but Hwaro definitely sets the bar high for Korean that is approachable and modern with a nod to traditions. Ina and her brother Ryan run a tight ship and service was excellent. We were able to get a table for two with no wait on a Saturday night--a definite plus in my book! The mushroom with kimchee and cheese was simple but amazingly delicious-- a must try. The fried chicken which comes on a hot plate is crispy and succulent. Get it half and half with garlic and sweet and spicy sauce. You won't be disappointed. We also got the bibimbap with hot stone which gave the rice a nice crispy crust. I can't wait to go back to try the other items!
author: Jeff K.

description: The ttukbokki was good but too stingy with the rice cakes. Felt like there were barely any in there and they were cut in half.
author: Jessica K.

description:
Came here for my kid's bday. He wanted to try a new Korean place ... we found this place and thought we would try it.

Had the following:
- Taco trio: quite yummy; although two of the tacos tasted quite similar
- Bibimbab: very good; my kid loved it
- Kalbi: they actually use good quality meat!
- Soup: don't remember the name; it's the one that has pork belly, although I substituted that with vegetables ... it was spicy and delish!

Overall, I loved this place. All four of us walked out happy and stuffed.
author: Ankur V.

description:
Food poisoning.

I ordered taco sampler and the kimchee fried rice with pork for take out.

1 hour after eating the kimchee fried rice with pork..I did not feel good. I vomited non-stop from 11pm to 2am. I was contemplating going to the hospital. Still recovering the next day..

Bad pork? Or just not a clean chef?  never forget the risk of someone else handling and cooking your food.

This was my favorite korean spot and it was right by my house. Never eating here again.
author: Gabriel S.

description: Only skinny people eat here. The place is empty because the food is pretty bad.  It's not real Korean food.  I was looking forward to the chicken wings but it tasted like fatty chicken skin.  Nom nom
author: Fatty A.

description:
First time coming here, it's Valentine's day. Thought we give this place a try since we live up the hill from here. (Support the neighborly restaurant)

2 Stars because we waited over 45 minutes for our food. Other half of our food never came where we just cancelled overall and asked for the check. Waited another 5-7minutes, but at this point we just wanted to leave. Husband had to go up to the register to pay, he waited in line for another 3-4minutes (since it was a long line of TO GO DELIVERY ORDERS. Took us a grand total of 1hr and 40 minutes at the restaurant, not intentionally.

Based on the food we DID receive...
- Japchae topped with Bulgogi was pretty good 
- Seafood pancake was flavorless, not crispy enough and too doughy 

We had originally also ordered Fried Chicken, half original half sweet spicy. And a side of rice.

Unfortunately we won't be back, at least not until they get their system together. Plus everything was kind of on the pricier side. The overall experience didn't feel very comfortable because you can feel how overwhelm everyone was, customers and employees and the owner.

Plus, the tables were places SO closed to each other we can hear our neighbors convos and vice versa.
author: Eva H.

description: Best new find for homey Korean food!! Love the Kimchi  Fried Rice with Pork, Bulgulgi and Hangover Soup.  Finally a new destination in the city without going down to the South Bay.....
author: Jen W.

description:
I really had high hopes for this place being that it had the chutzpah to open up in a place like the Excelsior, but the food just wasn't that good. :(

Ordered the tteokbokki and the fried chicken. The fried chicken was expensive at $17 and I was hesitant to get it because of that, but my friend said let's just go ahead and try it because you can't go wrong with fried chicken. Well, this fried chicken just wasn't that good. I felt like the batter was too thick and a bit flavorless despite the garlic it came topped with. I can understand using a thick batter to get a good crunch to the chicken, but I really didn't enjoy it. :(

The tteokbokki was drowning in a sauce that had a strange artificial and syrupy taste that I didn't enjoy either. It came served in a big, wide bowl, but the actual portion of rice cake seemed a bit small for the price.

Another problem I had was with the seating at the tables to the left hand side of the restaurant. The tables were so uncomfortably close to each other! I felt like I was having dinner and listening to the drama of the diners intimately next to me. There was so much space in the middle of the room being unused. Why? Is it for special events?

The food wasn't good and it was expensive for the quality. Definitely not coming back and not recommending Hwaro to others. Sorry. Skip this place and go to the Korean restaurants at Westlake in Daly City or the one at the end of Ocean Ave.

And I just realized, NO BANCHAN. I'm even more disappointed now.
author: Enari L.

description: Lived in this area for many years and have not noticed this restaurant until recently when I found it on Yelp. Most likely this restaurant was opened recently, since this area was known for their empty storefronts that sat empty for years. This is literally the only Korean restaurant in the Excelsior. I believe that this restaurant took over the former Goldilocks Bakery space. Walked into the restaurant and noticed the divey and hipster look with a bar on the right that serves beer, wine and soju. We ordered their Sweet and Spicy Fried Chicken and Tteok Bokki (Rice Cake) with Ramen. The Fried Chicken had a very nice breading and the sauce was not too spicy. The Tteok Bokki had a similar sauce to the Fried Chicken, but was not as spicy. We also added ramen to the Tteok Bokki, but the portion of ramen was very small. The service here was okay for a Friday night with not too many customers. The service was not very attentive, despite there being two waiters working and three tables occupied in the restaurant. The waiters actually forgot to bring us our beer. Overall a good addition to the Excelsior, but the service and portions of the food can be better.
author: Peter C.

description: Hwaro is a must try Korean spot. This restaurant is unique compared to other traditional Korean restaurants because it has food on the menu that I have never tried before, more closer to a fusion restaurant. Came to the restaurant on a slower day and I would say that I was very impressed with the food and service, definitely a restaurant I would come back to
author: Stevenson C.

description:
Food - 4 stars
Ambience - 3.5 stars

We ordered the king mushroom and asparagus for appetizers. Both were delicious. For our main course, I can comment that the BBQ is very well done here. I highly recommend the kalbi short ribs and the eel. Both were incredibly delicious. We were very disappointed to learn that they were all out of the Korean fried chicken probably because the table to my right ordered the last bit of fried chicken, did not finish and boxed it up to take home :( , so we ordered the bulgogi beef instead. I do not recommend that dish, it was quite bland. 

The ambience could be further improved by adding more seating, diming the lights in the dining area and more lighting behind the bar area (current lighting arrangement makes the restaurant seem closed). I recommend this restaurant be attentive to the small details on the walls (for example, the screws on the big knife and fork were very large and visible. 

All in all, I will be back again for another try, and hopefully be able to get my hands on those Korean fried chicken.
author: Jenelle L.

description: Love this place. Hangover soup, Jabchae and taco trio were delicious!  Highly recommend if you are new to Korean cuisine. Food tastes very authentic. Cheers!
author: EunJoo C.

description:
The closest Korean restaurant I could possibly ask for. This place is a fusion so if you're looking for "authentic" Korean food, look elsewhere. They serve one of my favorite Korean soups: the hangover soup which, for some reason, is rarely ever offered in other restaurants. I'd say that you definitely dont need to order a lot to get filled up unless you have a huge appetite or want more variety. I still want more banchan though lol

The waiters and waitresses are all very nice people and can accommadate you whenever possible. If you sit at the bar/really long table, the waiters dont mind talking to you. It's really a shame that they only open for dinner now. In the beginning, they opened for lunch but I guess there's too little business in this part of town during that time. =(
author: Victoria H.

description: I think this place just opened recently as there aren't that many reviews for it. Stopped by on a Weds night between Christmas and New Years to meet up with a friend for dinner. We order the tacos, fried chicken (half & half), and house salad. I really enjoyed everything. The tacos were for sure my favorite though. They were filled with tastiness! House salad was also very well dressed overall. It was quite large and definitely a good size to share. For the fried chicken, I would recommend just getting the sweet & spicy. The regular fried chicken is just pretty basic. It cost a little more to get half an half, so save your self a little bit and get just the sweet & spicy. Three dishes for us left us even leftovers. The service is good. They are pretty attentive and serve you water all the time. They also have alcohol on tap as well in case you're looking for a night cap.
author: Julie L.

description: The food they have here was very good and moderately priced as well. The garlic fried chicken was quite a hit for me. I loved the flavor and I made it my favorite dish here! The spice level for the other dishes here were definitely something to warn those who have low tolerance to spicy foods. Nevertheless, all them were delicious!
author: Natasha R.

description: I came here around 7pm on a Saturday night and got seated pretty quick. My friend and I ordered the kimchi fried rice, taco trio (this was one of their popular and must try dish) I wasn't disappointed because it was so good! We also got the wings (1/2 garlic and 1/2 spicy). The wings was so tasty. I would definitely be back and try their other dishes!
author: Louise C.

description: The bibimbap is the best! Worth ordering in the hot stone for the full flavor experience. $16 but it is a good sized portion and has a lot of ingredients. I will definitely be back!
author: Shannanigans001 ..

description:
Great food, great people, jazz music. 
Simply beautiful.

Try the hangover and the kimchi soup!
author: Katerina S.

description: I'm Korean and have tried several Korean restaurants in TX and CA. Best Spicy Beef Soup (Yuk-Gae-Jang) and Spicy Squid in SF!! Highly recommend!!! Staff are very kind and nice. Decent Korean food place you should try! :-)
author: Sam P.

description: Very good, we got the kimchi soup and the taco trio and it was very filling. The soup was more than enough for two people and the taco trio was also very tasty. Will return.
author: Andrés Q.

description: 2 stars for trying. Korean fusion. Great idea, but IMO wrong location. Pretty expensive for such a simple menu and especially in this part of SF.  portions are medium to small depending on what you order. Parking is very limited and tight.  Food was ok only. To make the effort here it would have to be mind blowing. Employees are nice and service was OK only. during the evenings be aware of your surroundings. There is so many competitors to drive to.
