Honestly if you goto a traditional Korean restaurant you will get more bang for your buck in comparison to this place.
author: Cee B.

description:
Really great food!

Has a nice atmosphere, especially if you want a few drinks with your food.

The food could be spicier, great flavors though.
Yu ke jang: great portion, not a lot of noodles but more beef than most places in SF give.

Dukbokki: could have had more rice noodles, but large helping of cheese and ramen on top. Sweet not spicy

Korean ramen was good too.

Will be going back to try more soon!
author: Ellie M.

description: Really liked this place, good service and food.  I recently moved here from the Richmond district where we had some of the best Asian food in the city within a short walk, so I was worried about our prospects here, but those worries have been soothed.  I've never seen a lot of people in there though...so if you want good Korean food and live around here please go here!  You won't be disappointed!
author: Bill H.

description: The garlic fried chicken was amazing!! The staff was very friendly, and helpful with the menu.
author: Cory T.

description:
This was amazing. I was honestly shocked just how good it was. 

I got the pork belly grill plate. My wife got the steak. Portions were huge--and so delicious. I first thought it was a little pricey--then I saw what you got. Worth every single penny. My mom ordered she Kimchi fried rice too, by the way. We are all really happy. 

This place is another addition to what the hood needs. Great food, great spot, great service. Thanks so much, I will be back.
author: Chad G.

description:
I'm beyond impressed by everything we ordered tonight!! We got sizzling pork belly, asparagus, King oyster mushroom, hangover soup, and garlic fried chicken! Every dish is delicious, garlic fried chicken and sizzling pork belly are my favorite. Service is wonderful, even though they just opened for 1 week(no advertising, not even soft opening yet) it's already crowded and throughout the night till they close.
I can't wait for the grand opening!!! Will definitely go back and invite my friends there.
author: Fanny Z.

description: Good neighborhood spot to eat at. Came in during dinner and there was no wait time. The trio tacos were the bomb dot com. Clean space and nice open set up. Waiters were also pretty nice and friendly
author: Luis T.

description: I use to live right on Sta Rosa Street.  This Korean place finally opened... I am impressed.  Met the owner Ina,  her staff in the kitchen is her Mom and brother.  The restaurant is family business,  she has another place at International restaurant on Kearney.  The food is very authentic and "good".  We order the hangover soup, the sizing pork belly,  garlic friend chicken,  asparagus and mushrooms.
author: SFoodie P.

description:
Having recently moved to SF from Los Angeles, it was a pleasant surprise to find a Korean restaurant in the vicinity. Customer service was a bit lacking as  I had to keep waiting for the waiter.

The four stars is reflected only on the quality of food. Ordered the kimchi fried rice, which tasted decent but it's far from the best I've had. It wasn't too spicy for those heat lovers and the flavors were definitely there but the price was a bit much for my liking. 

Customer service would've definitely dropped this place to a 3.5 stars but it's still not a bad Korean restaurant to check out in the end.
author: Anson L.

description: The food was unexpectedly good, we came here and we're surprised by their good service and wonderful food!!!
author: Joe C.

description: Good food and service. They put a good spin on traditional asian dishes and every dish we had was good.  Not the best but pretty good.  Service is the most stand out thing actually of this place.  All the servers are respectful and kind. Highly recommend this place.
author: paul k.

description:
Went there last night and enjoyed the experience/food.

Definitely love having different types of restaurants in the outer mission area. Not many other restaurants besides mexican or chinese food, so korean was a welcome change.

The interior and decor was very unexpected in a good way.  Modern and minimal design with large open space. 

Things we ordered:

- Rice cake skewer
fried/grilled korean rice cake with a sweet spicy sauce.  Texture was great, crunchy outside, gooey inside.  Sauce was nice and balanced.  One thing I would suggest to make it even better is to add some green onion slices in between the rice cakes. Also some sesame seeds on top.  I think that would bring out another level of flavor.

- Grilled eel plate
Comes out with dipping sauce, ginger, and lettuce to make wraps.  Awesome flavor and perfectly cooked.  Highly recommend getting this.

- Garlic and sweet spicy fried chicken
Flavor of the sweet garlic sauce was good.  Sweet and spicy sauce was similar to the one on the rice cake skewers. The chicken is pretty big and filling. The batter is pretty fluffy which makes the chicken look massive.  
Personal preference here, I don't prefer fried chicken with this fluffy kind of tempura batter, wish there was less batter or a different kind, my go to standard for asian chicken wings is at SO.  But with that said, I know others like this style, and the batter/breading was done well.

- Cold bibim buckwheat noodle
Flavor was good and the sauce was nice and balanced.
One suggestion is that it did not come with a hard boiled egg, or a slice of meat, which I think would complete the dish.  Also the portion was pretty small for the price, especially considering that an egg or beef slices were not in the dish.


Overall, I enjoyed the restaurant especially considering it being in the outer mission area. I would give this place 3 1/2 stars, but bumped it up for location, service, and since it only just opened.

Definitely going to come back to see how it progresses, and once they get their liquor/beer/wine license. They have a nice bar setup, and hope they have some nice beers on tap (always goes good with fried chicken).
author: Baek C.

description: What a great new neighborhood spot! We tried it out on a Saturday night. It wasn't too busy--we got a table right away, but it filled up as we were there. We ordered the taco trio (it was not really my favorite. I'd skip it next time), sweet and spicy fried chicken (Korean fried chicken is so damn good), and pork belly. There was a mixup in the kitchen and we didn't get our pork belly, but they were very apologetic about it and brought us free seaweed salad (REALLY GOOD), and we'd definitely over-ordered and by that point we were too full for it anyway. The vibe in there is really nice and the service was maybe a little slow, but we weren't really in any hurry. Overall really good experience, even with the mixup over the food. They handled it very professionally. I'm definitely going back to try the rest of the menu.
author: Laura S.

description: Yummmmmm!! It was so delicious. The bbq short ribs were just fantastic. Bulgogi, taco trio, fried chicken and fried rice. Everything was just great and the service was excellent!
author: Kris K.

description: Best Korean food in San Francisco and A new hidden secret! Family business which you can actually enjoy modern home cooked Korean meals made with a generous heart.
author: Carlos S.

description:
Came here when I was randomly trying to fill my Korean food craving and was surprised to see they opened this spot in the Excelsior/Mission area. My experience was overall good, it just seems they are still working out some kinks with a new opening (just received alcohol license). Service was also very friendly and accommodating!

- Taco Trio was not too bad, would probably order it again. 3.5/5 Stars
- Kimichi Soup was pretty good. It came with lots of pork belly, but the soup taste was just ok. Serving size is pretty large, so might be advised to share with someone if possible. 3.5/5 Stars

Haven't had a chance to try the pork belly plate or galbi, so i'll most likely update this review once I try all those. 

Overall, I think the place has great potential and it is definitely has one of the nicer interiors in the area. Will definitely be returning soon. Please add a TV, that would really make it even better. :)
author: Mario P.

description:
As a Korean native, this place cured my homesickness. Hwaro offers authentic modern korean dishes in a humble, clean environment. Unlike other Korean restaurants with a menu book of 10 pages, their menu is simple but various enough to satisfy different tastes. 

My boyfriend and I tried friend chickens (half garlic, half sweet spicy), pork belly bbq, hangover soup, and ddeok go chi  -- The portion was huuuuge and all the dishes were served fast. If you go there in big group, it would really be nice to share different plates. 

They are on the soft open period and are expected to fully open in 2 weeks. I am so looking forward to seeing it growing!
author: Juwon K.

description: I'll be back. We had some Korean tacos, fried chicken, and BiBimBap. Topped off with an OB pilsner, total with tax and tip was just under $60. Tacos were awesome in flavor. One problem was that it was hard to know what kind of meat was in the taco because of the flavoring added to it. Fried chicken wasn't bad - tasted like typical buffalo wings, except they were gigantic. We had the garlic and spicy and sweet. Both weren't bad - better than Buffalo Wild Wings for sure. The BiBimBap was pretty typical of what you would get at almost any Korean restaurant. All in all, quite good tasting food with a nice ambience.
author: Alton Y.

description:
This place is amazing! Every time I come in I practically inhale all of my food. I would say my favorite things to order are the Pork Belly, Yuk Ge Jang, and all of the fried chicken. 
FOOD:
Pork Belly: Umm yes I'll have another round! I am someone who typically does not enjoy pork at all and I almost always order this dish. The miso one is the best I would say. It has a salty miso flavor and the meat just melts in your mouth. No regrets when I get this.
Yuk Ge Jang: This is perfect for the cold gloomy days of San Francisco. I'm in love with spicy food and this is the perfect amount of spice. It's the perfect balance of spicy and salty. The portion of this soup blows my mind, I'm a big eater and I end up with leftovers.
Fried Chicken: GET IT. I like getting it half garlic and half sweet/spicy. For those who claim to like garlic and complain about the amount of garlic that comes on the chicken.... you're clearly not the garlic lover you thought you were. I love mixing the sweet/spicy sauce and the garlic together to get that all in one burst of yummy flavors.
KIMCHI: Hands down the best kimchi I've ever had. It's house made by owner's mother so that must be why. Nothing like a mom's touch.

SERVICE:
The wait staff is always super friendly and are always ready to answer the millions of questions I have. Some nights when I come in it is pretty hectic with a full house but I can tell they are trying their best and that's all we could ask for really. I've seen the owners floating around the restaurant from time to time and they are always so sweet to their customers.

All I have to say is try this place out and thank me later.
author: Siren L.

description:
Hwaro is a sure hit - their focus on quality of ingredients is a rarity among Korean restaurants in SF (and even greater Bay Area). If you're just looking for your typical Korean BBQ on a grill and copious amounts of mediocre banchan, this is not the place! You're not going to leave with uncomfortably bloated stomachs, mild ulcers and/or numbed tastebuds from overindulgence of spices. Newsflash non-koreans, that's not what makes Korean food great. If you actually care about the experience of authentic, refreshing and innovative cuisine, check it out.

Galbi - I usually don't get ribs at restaurants b/c hey... i can make it too. The meat was just the right amount of juicy and sweet, with the familiar taste of smoky grill. But what makes this one special is the napa cabbage accompanying the meat. It's so sweet and fresh! I'm so sick of the typical lifeless (and pesticide-lain) cabbage at other korean places, and I usually don't touch them. However, with the right amount of doenjang (soybean paste) and a morsel of meat... the refreshing crunch of the cabbage was so good! mmhmmm!

Stuffed Mushroom - this was an innovative dish that caught my eye. You get a large portobello mushroom stuffed with bulgogi and cheese on top. Great appetizer and intro to Korean flavors!

Yukgejang - this is a semi-spicy soup that reminds me of my grandmother. Again, I don't order this at restaurants because most of them put too much korean pepper flakes in the soup making your stomach pretty uncomfortable later. This place puts just the right amount of pepper - you get that crisp & spicy flavor that soothes your nostrils (this is my best attempt to translate a korean phrase to describe this type of spiciness; it has no equivalent english words) without feeling bad about yourself later on.

The highlight of my experience was the dessert! We got warm hotteok (korean street food - basically sugar and cinnamon in a pancake that's fried crisp on the outside and gooey and sticky inside) and vanilla ice cream. I can't believe I never thought of this combination! Imagine an asian version of crepe with cinnamon & sugar a la mode. It's sprinkled with matcha to add a little kick to the taste and nuts to round out the flavors.
author: S H.

description:
My wife and I were staying with family in the Excelsior over the holidays, and wanted to go out for dinner without going too far. We decided to try Hwaro, and were very pleasantly surprised.

We didn't sample a large range of dishes. In fact, we each just had a vegetarian bi-bim-bap. She had the regular, and I had the dolsot (hot stone) version. You don't get the large range of side-dishes that some Korean restaurants serve--just a bit of kimchi and pickled cucumber--but it was plenty of food, and the flavors were excellent.

The staff were all very nice and friendly, and the jazz music gives the place a nice atmosphere. I would definitely go back.
author: Michael H.

description: It tastes nothing like korean food. More like a chinese fusion. We had kimchi fried rice, trio taco and japchae..
author: Ellie D.

description: Great hangover food during brunch hours. Hidden gem in the Ecselcior district. Nice decor. Good service. Might be hard to find cuz the sign is tiny.
author: Marvin R.

description: Long wait for delivery drivers. No accommodations or apologies offered. Recommend skipping this one
author: Don W.

description:
New and only korean restaurant in the neighborhood, so I needed to give this place a try. 
Service*****
Attentive waiters and waitress. Was seated upon arrival. 

Yuk Ke Jang *****
Spicy beef noodle soup. Very flavorful. 

Garlic Fried Chicken *****
Fried chicken with a little sweet sauce and lots of minced garlic. 

Kimchi Fried Rice ***
The taste was there, but the rice was too moist.
author: Sylvia C.

description:
My friend and I decided to try this place out because we were craving Korean Fried Chicken. The sweet-and-spicy fired chicken was our favorite as the garlic chicken was a bit too overpowering. They dab the glaze rather than tossing it more like other places, such as Bonchon. Aside from the glaze, the chicken was crunchy but moist on the inside!

Overall, it wasn't a bad place and I would return again in the future.
author: Lester U.

description: Glad to see a good Korean spot in the excelsior! Very inviting with a wonderful hospitality. The food is also very good and fresh. I ordered the Korean ramen, it is instant ramen yet has a comforting element. Their kalbi is also very good and they serve you a good portion. If you are in the area you should definitely stop here.
author: Kayla L.

description: Omg this place is AH-MAZING. All the food is so flavorful!! The kimchi is divine. The soup and meat were all fabulous. Highly recommended.
author: Nicole W.

description: Food was delicious and Customer Service was on point, servers went above and beyond! Minor setbacks was our group table lacked lighting and we thought there would be more banchon, typical of korean restaurants.
author: Mack S.

description: Really good Korean food. Even better that it's in the mission because there's not too many of these places around. They have a good special of 50% off bottles of wine on Wednesday which drew me in.
author: Benji S.

description: Came here on a Friday night with some friends! The service was great and the food was spectacular! We had the pork belly, fried chicken, the corn cheese dish and lots of pineapple soju! It was such a great meal! I can't wait to go back! So glad it's in the neighborhood! Too bad it's only open for dinner but hopefully they will open for lunch in the near future! Great vibe! Looking forward to trying other items on the menu!
author: raquel t.

description: Might just be my new go to when I need something super warm and comforting  Can't wait see what they have to offer for brunch!!
author: Kris S.

description: So glad to have this clean, tasty, Korean restaurant in the hood.  Some interesting snacks, like corn and mozzarella cheese.  Solid Korean hits, BiBimBap, japchae, bulgogi.   I love the Chinese dives as much as the next person, but sweet lord, we need some variety! Hwaro provides a nice departure, in food and the atmosphere.
author: Susie M.

description:
Some context:

-3/5 of our party was slightly sick with variations of the flu (on the recovering end though)
-I don't eat at high end restaurants
-We went near Christmas

(scroll to bottom for tl;dr if too much)

THIS PLACE HAS POSSIBLY SOME OF THE BEST CUSTOMER SERVICE EVER. The two waitresses were SUPERB. Brought food quickly, checked on us regularly, and graciously fulfilled all our requests ("Can we have more napkins?" "Could we get a refill of water?" "Could we also get some hot water?" "Could we get some plates?" "Actually, could we get bowls instead?") It was at the point where we felt bad for asking, but they never once showed annoyance. Freaking fantastic. I'll come back to the customer service in a bit.

Food was yummy, even for our impaired taste buds (remember how some of us were sick?) We ordered 2 seafood ramens, 1 spam ramen, 1 kimchi fried rice, 1 wakame salad, and a half-and-half order of fried chicken composed of sweet-spicy, and garlic. Seafood had LOTS of great seafood in it (mussels, shrimp, squid) and was quite flavorful. Not advertised as spicy, but it is mildly spicy. Spam ramen was also spot-on. Kimchi fried rice was delicious, but portion felt a little small (everyone gobbled it up though). Advertised as spicy, and also felt mildly spicy. Wakame salad was your standard seaweed salad, but it was stacked pretty tall. Felt pretty good for $4. Fried chicken was so delicious, even though some of us had to peel off the fried stuff cause of our sore throats :( :( STILL freaking good.

Note: it IS a fusion spot, so we didn't get the usual Korean appetizers that come with the meal. Not a big deal to us since the meal itself was super yum.

Price? For the 5 of us, after tips and tax, we were sub $100. Probably because we chose some of the cheaper menu items. Regardless, DEFINITELY worth every penny.

Now for the kicker. We ate around 7:30, and we finished our food round about 8:30 ish. We were taking our time, and it was luckily a quiet night. Waitresses never bugged us, never hurried us. When we finished, we did a White Elephant game, and then played Exploding Kittens (one of the gifts). Still, waitresses did not bug us or rush us. They brought the check over, and told us not to hurry. We played until about 9:30, then we went over to ask for a knife for our cake. We felt kind of bad since we had just paid the check and were now asking for extra service...But the waitress happily cleaned a a really nice cake knife (full tang, nice heft to the handle) and got a bunch of plates and metal forks (I was about to ask for paper plates and plastic forks though...). These ladies were really going above and beyond. We finished our cake, and then left an extra $10 for the trouble.

Tl;dr this place is freaking amazing, with absolutely phenomenal customer service to match the delicious food. Do keep in mind the contextual bullet points I started with.
author: Filmer Y.

description: Pretty sure the ramen is just instant ramen with a little bit of egg, onion, and green onions.
author: jean m.

description: This is a super cute place hat not many would notice, though it's in a weird neighborhood, the restaurant vibe makes it classier and more elegant. The food was pretty good, especially the bulgolgi, but I would skip on the seafood pancake. It was pretty dry, overall it was a great place to chill after work and have a nice hat with friends.
author: Martina L.

description: If you're on the south side of the city, craving Korean food/BBQ, and don't feel like schlepping to the Richmond then come to Hwaro! It's more traditional than Namu but still has some California flair. The Korean bar food is tasty (corn cheese,  and did someone say Korean fried chicken?!?), plus they have more traditional BBQ (not cook at the table bit sizable portions on a sizzzzzzzling plate), dishes and soups. And they have their beer/wine license now so get some soju!!
author: Sig N.

description:
Walked in at 7:30 on a Saturday night. Bar was totally empty, and there were probably 4-5 empty tables. One big table of 20+ celebrating something was the bulk of the clientele.

Sat at the bar and ordered two dishes:

The Korean taco trio
 Chopped cooked steak and pork with hot kimchi and other seasonings.
 These were drowning in a pink mayo which was ok, but i could have done with one eigth or less the amount. Kind of gross.

the Korean fried chicken
 The seasonings were good (fresh garlic topping, and sweet and sour) but when it comes to Korean fired chicken, I prefer a much thinner, crispier batter.

I live nearby and there isn't another Korean option anywhere nearby. So I might come back to sample the bibimbop or bulgolgi, since those are very different dishes.
author: C H.

description: I'm giving this a 4 for now because I only got take out and never ate physically at a table. With that being said, I had ordered the hangover soup, kalbi, sweet and sour chicken wings, spicy squid, and seafood ramen to share between my family and I. We definitely got what we paid for. The food was not cheap but it sure was delicious. The flavor of the food exceeded our standards and expectations of Korean food.
author: Rachel L.

description:
they literally served me McDonalds fries.  

also they do not serve alcohol. so, yeah. 

those fries. they were "Kimchi Fries" (went with a vegetarian friend and this was one of the menu items we were reduced to, so....heads up vegetarians!), and this was basically a platter of MCDONALDS FRENCH FRIES HOT OFF THE LINE.  with a spooge of steaming, wilty, soggy kimchi plopped on top of them.  lets be real.  we all know a McDonalds fry when we eat it.  these things were hot off the drive-thru line.  like, we almost went out back after our meal to look for fry containers in the dumpster.  alas, we were in too much of a rush to leave this place and never. ever return.

oh, and you want an alcoholic beverage after you come to the above realization. trust me.
author: Leah P.

description:
I always tell it as it is. 

My bf and I decided to try out this place after hearing reviews from friends. We arrived to the spot around 8pm. The place was full but not packed... seats were available so we didn't have to wait. The overall ambiance was nice. The decor was trendy and modern. They were fully staffed.. I spotted about 6+ workers on the floor. Most were gathered behind the cash register. The 1st waiter came over and offered waters...but didn't end up actually bringing it. Another female server approached us after and offered menu and waters but forgot to bring the waters. Then she came back to take our order and later on brought us our drinks. We ordered 3 items in total: stuffed mushrooms, garlic pork belly and kimchi pancake. The mushrooms came out before we got our drinks. The utensils didn't get to us until we bugged the server for the 2nd time. We tried the first 2 items and agreed that the food was amazing! Before we could even finish the 2nd dish, another heavier set female server came over and asked us if we were ready for the check. We looked at her in confusion because it was clear we were still eating and waiting for the remaining dish. She went back to the kitchen to check on it...and realized they forgot our order. The owner came out and apologized while we waited. The 3rd dish finally came and we started to eat. Within a 10 min time frame, the heavier set female server came and rudely interrupted again and asked about the bill. We finally decided to get the check and a box to take our items to go. We didn't understand why she was being so rude when they had 30 min til close and the restaurant was still packed. She placed the bill on top of our to go box, did not say thank you, and rudely stormed off. Clearly, she has no respect for customers and shows zero appreciation for her job. The only reason why I would ever visit again is for the food and food only. The owner should really reevaulate who she hires. It makes all the difference when it comes to customer service and the reputation of the business. My bf and I never tip below 20% but we only tipped 13% today. 

Pros: 
- owner was friendly, floor present, and eager to assist.

- food was delicious and worth the money (perfect temperature, meat was seasoned very well, and every dish met our expectations)

- nice ambiance (modern light fixtures, cute decor, homely feeling)

- street parking available nearby

- they allow you to bring in your own alcohol since they aren't serving just yet.

Cons:

- rude heavy set female server 
- inexperienced servers
- they forgot our order 
- every server that came to check in only asked about the bill and nothing else.

Go check it out for yourself. Food was worth the money.
author: L W.

description: As much as I would like to claim I'm a foodie, I should write reviews more often! Anyways, We really loved Hwaro. Only problem is that it's on the other side of town. But I can drive a few miles for good food. They have really modernized Korean cuisine and yet remained close to traditional Korean fare. Their asparagus on a sizzler, cheese/kimchi on a sizzler were outstanding! So different from what you would get anywhere else. Their dried chicken was light, not doused in oil, crispy and moist on the inside! Service was really nice as well - not the usual rushed experience you get in the packed traditional Korean restaurants. Give this place a shot. You'll love it!
author: Arun M.

description:
This is a review for their food only.  (Since it seems that they need to work on their services, if I compare the service to a term paper, this would be a very rough draft)
The garlic fried chicken: 
Not your standard korean fried chicken that one would conjure up, this one looks big and crunchy on the outside but juicy on the inside with tons of garlic.  What's wrong with that picture you ask? Chicken is flavorless, the outside coating is like a baggy giant coat hanging on the meat for dear life.  The garlic is plentiful... sounds like a garlic lovers' paradise however this big dollop of mince garlic is as raw as it gets and is somehow mixed with sugar but without any salt. The end result? Plain overpriced flavorless fried chicken that makes you cry tears of garlickyness with a hint of sugar.  (If you really want to order it please bring salt and pepper with you)
The redeeming seafood pancake:
The only reason why I am giving them 3 stars, the sauce was spot on.  The pancake was light, crunchy and with plenty of ingredients in there.  The calamari legs in there was soft and juicy, the cabbage added a nice texture to the light and fluffy pancake.  Thumps up all the way.
The other dishes that my friends order weren't that great either for the price. 
Will I go back? Not likely.
author: Suzanne L.

description: The ambiance at Hwaro is great, while the food is okay. For people who enjoy heavier foods like red meat, noodles and fried food, there are plenty of choices. For those who like vegetables and non-fried dishes, there is very little to choose from. The staff is attentive and friendly. My wife liked the gyoza and my daughter liked the fried chicken. The hangover soup is very spicy. I hope they expand their menu of lighter, healthier foods. I live in the neighborhood and look forward to coming back and giving it a second chance.
author: Ethan C.

description: I came with my Korean friend and he really love the food here. We ordered spicy beef soup, spicy squids, and seafood pancake. Everything is tasty.
author: Panukarn Y.

description: Mediocre food. Nothing special. No free side dishes and all. They got so many servers but lacks of customer service. They did not even greet us when we first came in. Only 2stars because of the lady server name Serena because she was nice. That's all but wont come back again.
author: Em Q.

description: Great new addition to the Excelsior dining scene.  They are still in a soft opening phase and refining their stellar menu.  Staff is all new, but working hard to keep customers happy.  The eel, pork belly and bulgogi are all amazing.  They have both fresh kimchee as a side and some of the best fermented kimchee I've ever had served with certain dishes such as the pork belly.  The Korean fried chicken is also amazing- especially if you love garlic.  The owner could not be nicer or more eager to please.  I've eaten there three times in the last two weeks and can't wait to try everything on the menu, as nothing has disappointed to date.
author: C. W.

description: It's ok... no bibimbap, which is crazy talk to me if it's called a Korean restaurant. Good space and ambiance. Bulgogi doesn't come with rice, and Soups do? Strange... but ok. Fried chicken looked and smelled good. Wait staff seems inexperienced, but they try hard. Might visit again, since this is the only Korean place in a 6 block radius.
author: gary l.

description: As a Korean, I have been to both Authentic Korean and Korean fusion restaurants. When often times some of these other restaurants either cook the same thing again and again or lose their DNA by overdoing the fusion thing, Hwaro is by far one of the best places by combining all the flavors, textures and presentations. I tried various dishes and they were all so delicious! The service is great; all various ingredients were perfectly cooked with the right texture and seasoning; the menu is so diverse and with each bite, you feel the love from a family run kitchen!
author: Philippe L.

description:
Updated 5/14/17
We had dinner last night with two friends and re-affirm the review wrote about three weeks ago (below).  We might add that the restaurant was full around 6:30 PM on Saturday, and the noise level was not quite as loud as we had feared, in spite of families with children being there.  We were greeted warmly and had our reserved tables waiting for us.  The combination tacos, Portobello mushrooms stuffed with bulgogi were again outstanding.  We had japchae, a Korean clear noodle dish in addition to our usual Kalbi, spicy pork belly, Bibimbap, and the Hangover soup, which were all excellent.  Our friends also loved the food and the restaurant, a discovery for them. Glad we came back!

Previous Review, April, 2017
An outstanding Korean/Fusion restaurant with creative and flavorful food.  We came here from across town based on reviews because we wanted to find a Korean restaurant that was worthy of bringing knowledgeable friends, and the trip was not wasted.  Coming rather early on a Saturday evening, we were greeted warmly and had a choice of tables (They do accept reservations by phone, only when they are open after 5 PM).  We ordered the combination tacos (bulgogi+pork belly, bulgogi+kimchi, and pork belly+kimchi), Portabella mushrooms stuffed with bulgogi, Bibimbop (rice mixed with various ingredients served in a hot stone bowl) , Hangover soup (spicy beef soup), Pork belly and Kalbi (broiled beef short ribs).  They served three little banchan (side dishes), consisting of spinach, kimchi, and a special sauce.  This may sound meager, but all the three items were delicious - the kimchi was fresh and flavorful (best we had among all Korean restaurants in the Bay Area), and the special sauce consisting of miso and hot sauce and garlic was outstanding in flavor!  Much better than many more side dishes which all taste bland as in some other Korean restaurants I reviewed.  The tacos were outstanding as was the portabella mushrooms stuffed with bulgogi - these fusion dishes were so flavorful they would not be out of place in Quince or Benu (see my reviews of these outstanding restaurants).  They serve a bowl of lettuce and Napa cabbage leaves, which can be used to wrap the pork belly, kalbi, or bibimbop with the special sauce, adding a fresh, crunchy contrast to the hot dishes.  The pork belly and kalbi were both seasoned just right and delicious and the bibombop in sizzling hot stone bowl was also delicious.  The spicy beef hangover soup was also very tasty and satisfying.  They have beer and wine and Korean special beverages - Soju (tastes like weak vodka) and Makgeolli (milky Korean rice wine).  We had both Soju and Makgeolli, but wife wound up ordering Sauvignon blanc (a very good one- Joel Gott).  Although located in a somewhat gentrifying neighborhood, the restaurant has a clean,  modern feel with nice murals, though the chairs could be more comfortable.  The service was very friendly and prompt.  We would recommend this restaurant for foodies like us who are willing to travel a bit to find a truly satisfying gastronomic experience.  Definitely will come again.  Their website indicates they also deliver thru Doordash or Uber Eats..
author: Hoyle L.

description: Modern spin on Korean food staples. Simple comfy decor and mixed crowd; a good representation of The E! Wait staff was very attentive and friendly. Had their kalbi, chopchae and hangover soup; tasty across the board. We threw in a bottle of soju for good measure and left happy. They were even so kind as to comp us the soju because it was our wedding anniversary! We dig it!
author: Joseph M.

description: First time here saw the great reviews had to check it out. Great!! Pork belly cheese corn appetizer and orange drink 20$!!! Maybe I won't miss goldilocks, great new spot in the E!!
author: Gregory H.

description:
Wow! The less said the better but this is more like a PSA so I'll elaborate. This place is Korean to the extent that I, an Indian male, could be Korean simply by changing my name to Kim Park or some other ridiculous stereotype. Do they play Bossanova? Yeah sure, but if I wanted to listen to Bossanova I wouldn't go to a bloody Korean restaurant would I? Can they make Kimchi fried rice? Yes but it turns out I can do it better if I were lost in the jungle with just some rice and kimchi and a rubber band. As in seriously better. And ramen? Sure they can make ramen but so did I when I was in college and used to buy the ready made ramen in the non-Asian grocery store. They literally didn't know what bori cha (roasted barley tea) is. And while they claimed that they added pork belly to the ramen, for which they charged an extra $2, that pig must have been starving because either they didn't give me pork belly or that pig did not have an ounce of fat on it's belly. 
Therefore: starving. As was I, after the whole thing was done because I couldn't stomach the idea that I had just had Korean food. Because I hadn't.
The service - well it's not the waitstaff's fault if some rich person decides to set up a restaurant which ostensibly serves Korean but in fact does not. They were trying their best but what level of service can make up for horrendous food? No level of service.
Now if you want to listen to Bossanova and drink water or soju or beer, by all means go to this place. But if you want Korean food, you are as likely to find it just about anywhere. Maybe even at the Salvadorean place nearby. I mean the probability is the same because apparently anything can pass off as Korean just by giving it a Korean name and attracting gentrifying hipsters with Ikea decor and Bossanova?!
author: ch d.

description: Living in LA I've had some of the best Korean food on the west coast. Hwaro's offerings are very average in comparison and joins SF's long list of disappointing Korean restaurants. I tried the cold noodles, Korean fried rice, Galbi and Kimchi Stew. Everything was average, the cold noodles were very disappointing, it was soggy and the flavor wasn't quite right
author: Charles W.

description:
Came here for dinner with five other co-workers and friends this week and this is a collective review from all of us lol. They must still be doing a soft opening as service is still somewhat lacking and the waitstaff could learn a few things. Maybe this isn't the best place for a big group-the food came staggered with me and another person's food coming first and then my last two co-worker's food coming a half an hour after we had already finished! The owner came out to explain why my friend's wings took so long (they had to re-do it) but no apologies. It was also hard to stomach seeing another friend's taco trio being delivered to a table of two that had come after us and had already two dishes on their table. So the service is spotty, how about the food?

-Yuk Ge Jang: Bland, broth was watery. I was definitely left hungry after.
-Pork Belly Platter: Flavor was very good, texture could be more tender. Questionable whether this was actually pork belly as there was hardly any fat and it was quite sturdy.
-Seafood Pancake: I didn't get to try this, but my two friends really liked it and would recommend it.
-Garlic Fried Chicken: Sweetened raw garlic slathered on top. Take away the raw garlic paste, the chicken itself was very bland. We think they added too much sugar to the raw garlic as it was almost sickly sweet.
-Sweet & Spicy Fried Chicken: This was a lot better, more flavorful. 
-Taco Trio: DEFINITELY the thing to get here. Not only is it a good value (they give you a SHIT-TON of meat-for now-for the price), the meats were very tender, piled on and flavorful. I wanted to actually order this after I tried my friend's but was afraid that it would take forever.
author: Jenny W.

description: Good Korean by far in SF/San Jose area. We're NYC Koreans and have been looking for a decent home cooked meal. The seasonings are not spicy for Korean palate but all the flavors were there. Kalbi is truly your LA Kalbi style cut and delicious. Better than any Korean place I've been to in SF or even San Jose.
author: GgrR K.

description: What a wonderful surprise in the Outer Mission. On a recent trip to Korea I fell in love with the food. So when I returned to S.F. I wanted to experience Korean food with the same authenticity as I encountered in Seoul. Hwaro delivered! The staff was so friendly and knowledgeable. The music was perfect and at just the right level. And then the food, wow! Every dish had honest flavors. I especially liked the  Rice cake Skewers as they brought me back to Korea. The Kimchi Soup will be my goto this winter on cold rainy nights. I also tried the Pork Belly  and Spicy Squid, both were delicious! The big Mushroom was stuffed with super tender and tasty Bulgogi And just when I thought I could not eat another bite, the Seafood  Pancake came out. It was better then the ones I had in Insa-dong. If you are craving authentic and honest Korean food , then this is THE place!
author: glenn w.

description: I picked this place to eat based on the high reviews and was pretty disappointed.  I felt hella bad for my friends bc I chose the place.  The place itself is nicely decorated, clean, service was prompt and polite but the food was bleh.  It's more of a white-washed Korean restaurant and my roommate is Korean so maybe I'm spoiled by great tasting Korean food.  We ordered the Korean tacos, cheese corn, seafood pancake and the combo chicken wings (garlic and spicy).  The Korean tacos were good but too much mayo on them (the portions are also very small), the seafood pancake was ok only (not disgusting but not something I would order again), it wasn't crunchy enough, the cheese corn tasted good but the portion was so small, the chicken wings were moist and cooked perfectly but there was barely any flavor on it.  The garlic was basically fried chicken with minced garlic on top, the chili one was fried chicken w/the bottled chili-garlic sauce put on top.  It was the most disappointing thing on the menu.  I can't believe a chef would just put a blob of sauce on top and claim that as dish they found fit to serve at a restaurant.  The best thing was the tacos and the cheese corn but portions are very small.  I wouldn't go back again.
author: Honey S.

description: This place is a great new spot! The service is friendly, the food is delicious. Definitely get the Taco Trio. A great sampling of different types of Korean tacos. At the moment you can even BYOB!
author: Luis I.

description: I tried Hwaro with my girlfriend and we ordered the seaweed salad, fries, kimchi fried rice with pork, and japchae. The seaweed salad was delicious but very small; I could've finished it in one bite. The fries were solid especially with the spicy mayo. They brought out my kimchi and it sat there for over 25 minutes until they finally brought out my girlfriends japchae. The restaurant was not busy at all either. The people sitting next to us had come in 10 min later than we did and got their food before us. The only thing we were offered was a "sorry about that small mistake". The staff were very friendly but this was unacceptable in my opinion. I don't understand why they couldn't have offered a little more than a simple apology. If I were the waiter in a situation like this, I would not have charged the customer for the meal that came out 25 minutes late. Overall the food was good but they need to figure out a better system of taking care of customers if they mess up.
author: Brandon M.

description: The food here is actually okay, but the service is terrible. Ordered food to go. Waited 45 minutes for it. Watch as the fries I ordered sat in the window for 20 minutes and asked if they were still crispy. The waiter said they were great. I knew the answer. End up getting home and they had forgotten one of the things I ordered. I asked him to take it off my charge as well as the soggy fries. He told me that they can't take things off of checks they have to delete the whole check and rering everything and then run my card again. I spent more time than I needed on the phone and in the restaurant. Long story short, the $70 charge showed up in my credit card. Slow clap for Hwaro and their poorly trained staff.
author: Greg H.

description: Loved the food here! I really enjoyed the authenticity of the food in a more modern setting. I definitely plan on coming back!
author: Brandon L.

description: The food are okay but it is a little overpriced. Don't order the asparagus because it is only few little piece but it charge for $6. I give 3 stars basically is because the service is good and I like the kimchi fried rice. I don't think I will go back again.
author: angel w.

description: New Korean restaurant with great food.  It still need some finishing touches but over all in the right track.  BYOB for now and the menu is limited.  It would be nice to see some more vegetarian dishes.  Their ramen is made with beef stock.  Kimchi pancake and kimchi rice are both good.  Prices are very reasonable. Music and decor still need help. I will definitely go back.
author: Ciocio S.

description: I would not recommend getting the ramen, as I've had packaged ramen that tastes better. For $10 it's definitely not worth the price.
author: Kyle F.

description: I wanted to like this place. I thought the food was decent and tasty for the price (although my friends disagree). Service was bad enough to actually warrant a yelp review. Very slow kitchen (45 minutes for a rice dish?). But the worst part was that the server ignored us to the point where I have to try to wave her down. She raises her hand to acknowledge and litetally returns to other tasks for another 10 minutes and never comes to check on us at all. I have to get up and walk to the back to check on my own order while my friends are already half way finished with their entrees. Awkward apology for the slow kitchen ensues from the other server when food finally arrives. To be honest, the slow kitchen wasn't nearly as bad as the lack of service. The owner clearly provides no service training to the staff and expects them to just figure it out (and expects customers to tolerate it).
author: J M.

description: Went there on a busy Saturday night. Although the service was a bit slow, we really enjoyed the food and the atmosphere. Unique dishes and jazz music + some really nice wine = awesome night.
author: Kostas S.

description: Been here three times now.  Good food each time.  They have been expanding the menu a bit and so I will be heading back again soon for some bi bim bap which is one of my favorite breakfast foods.
author: John P.

description: Came by for dinner with a couple of friends.  We had bulgogi, taco trio, and kalbi.  Love the food.  Love the staff, especially Ina.  We were pleasantly surprised to find such a great Korean restaurant in the outside mission.  We would definitely come back again.
author: Anthony N.

description: My friend and I went on Christmas day for dinner. The place was packed and the service was great! I had the hangover soup and my friend had honey garlic chicken wings. The soup was really delicious and the portion was big! My friend loved his chicken wings. Will definitely come back again to try their other items!
author: Eddie T.

description: Came here last week had there gyozas  which were alright nothing special. I had the korean ramen which is basically the ramen that comes in a bag that you can cook yourself at home. It was ok. My friend had the korean spicy chicken wings which looked really good but once you took a bite they were just ok i've had better. The service was probably best part out of the whole experience. Everyone is very nice.
author: Genelle G.

description: Delicious Korean food in a hipster atmosphere. We had the taco trio, hangover soup, kimchee fried rice and fried chicken wings (garlic and spicy).  Everything was delicious. I'm Korean and have always complained about the lack of really good Korean food in the city. Finally, Hwaro is helping up the Korean food scene in SF. The dduk on the skewers appetizer is amazing. So perfectly crispy on the outside but soft as you bite in. Heaven!!!
author: Annabelle H.

description: they are one of the hip places in the neighbourhood, and answered questions about my gluten free issues patiently on phone.  however, I am not sure if they can make sure if their side dishes such as Kimchi and pickles are really gluten free (since korean soy sauce usually contains wheat flour). thats something they need to work better on.  also, I suspect they put MSG into their cooking. I heard MSG isnt necessarily a bad thing, but it does make me thirsty.
author: Shuting Z.

description: Couldn't be happier that this place has opened near my house. We now go once a week. Sweet and spicy fried chicken is to die for and can't get enough of the glass noodle dish. Staff are super friendly and food is cheap for the quality. Nice atmosphere but service can be a little slow and only due to the fact that the place is always full.
author: Relle C.

description: I'm thrilled that the Excelsior neighborhood got a Korean restaurant. Food was good, environment was modern and clean (this location is relatively new), and although the service could use a little bit of polish, I don't have any major complaints. For dinner we (2 of us) had: rice cake, kimchee fried rice (with an egg), and pork belly. I'd recommend all of it. We left stuffed and will definitely be back. Enjoy!
author: Ken C.

description: Been here for the first time and i was shock with quality of their food. It was amazing!!! Their fried chicken is off the hook! Their galbi is very well seasoned.  Authentic korean place in mission finally!!!
author: Tony K.

description:
as a korean-american raised on the east coast, i'm constantly surprised at the lack of really good korean food in sf.  after seeing the hwaro menu online, we were looking forward to giving it a try, especially since we live in bernal & it's in the south side of the city.  
acknowledging it wasn't a traditional korean restaurant, it was still a little disappointing.  at times, it seemed to want to be a traditional korean restaurant.  but then it also tried to be inventive & creative.  it didn't seem to accomplish either all that well.  
truthfully, after seeing the online menu before arriving, i was really hoping to have a bowl of bibimnaengmyun ("spicy buckwheat noodle"), one of my favorite korean dishes.  i was saddened to find it crossed off the menu.  my husband ordered the yuk ge jang.  i ordered the fried chicken from the "big plate" menu for my daughter & me (after asking the waitress if it'd be big enough to share with her, i was assured that it would be as there were ten pieces).
the yuk ge jang was hearty (though the portion of the accompanying kimchi/banchan was miniscule!).  the "big plate" of fried chicken turned out to be wings--very crispy with a great sauce, but hardly substantial enough for two people, even as an appetizer.  also wished the tea selection was more korean (i.e.  there's no boricha/barley tea, & it felt odd to have peppermint tea offered instead).
the service was friendly.  i think we might be wiling to give hwaro another try, now that our expectations have been altered.  but with other more traditional options available in the city & with namu gaji doing the korean fusion thing so well already, we might not.
author: jeanie c.
